sentence: When one of them receives a letter or packet, he runs full speed to the next village, where his approach being announced by the bells, another is ready to start and proceed to the next, and soon.

sectionTitle: The Couriers of the Great Khan and their Stations
sentence: By these pedestrian messengers the khan receives news in one day and night from places distant ten days' journey; in two, from those distant twenty ; and in ten, from those distant a hundred.

sectionTitle: The Couriers of the Great Khan and their Stations
sentence: From them he exacts no tribute, but gives them horses and many other things.

sectionTitle: The Couriers of the Great Khan and their Stations
sentence: When his messengers go on horseback to carry intelligence into the provinces or bring tidings from distant parts, and, more especially, respecting any district that has rebelled, they ride in one day and night 200, 260, or even 300 miles ;

sectionTitle: The Couriers of the Great Khan and their Stations
sentence: and when there are two, they receive two good horses, bind themselves round the head and body, and gallop fall speed from one station to the next at twentyfive miles' distance, where they find two others fresh and ready harnessed, on which they proceed with the same rapidity.

sectionTitle: The Couriers of the Great Khan and their Stations
sentence: They stop not for an instant day nor night, and are thus enabled to bring news in so short a period.

sectionTitle: The Couriers of the Great Khan and their Stations
sentence: Now, I will tell you the great bounty which the monarch bestows twice in the year.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: He sends his messengers through all his kingdoms and provinces, to know if any of his subjects have had their crops injured through bad weather or any other disaster ;

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: and if such injury has happened, he does not exact from them any tribute for that season or year ;

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: nay, he gives them corn out of his own stores to subsist upon, and to sow their fields.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: This he does in summer ;

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: in winter he inquires if there has been a mortality among the cattle, and in that case grants similar exemption and aid.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: When there is a great abundance of grain, he causes magazines to be formed, to contain wheat, rice, millet, or barley, and care to be taken that it be not lost or spoiled ;

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: then when a scarcity occurs, this grain is drawn forth, and sold for a third or fourth of the current price.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: Thus there cannot be any severe famine ;

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: for he does it through all his dominions;

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: he bestows also great charity on many poor families in Kambalu ;

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: and when he hears of individuals who have not food to eat, he causes grain to be given to them.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: Bread is not refused at the court throughout the whole year to any who come to beg for it;

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: and on this account he is adored as a god by his people.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: His majesty provides them also with raiment out of his tithes of wool, silk, and hemp.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: These materials he causes to be woven into different sorts of cloth, in a house erected for that purpose, where every artisan is obliged to work one day in the week for his service.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: Garments made of the stuffs thus manufactured are given to destitute families for their winter and summer dresses.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: A dress is also prepared for his armies ;

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: and in every city a quantity of woollen cloth is woven, being defrayed from the tithes there levied.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: It must be observed, that the Tartars, according to their original customs, when they had not yet adopted the religion of the idolaters, never bestowed alms ;

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: but when applied to by any necessitous person, repelled him with reproachful expressions, saying,- begone with your complaints of a bad season, God has sent it to you, and had he loved you, as he evidently loves me, you would have similarly prospered.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: But since some of the wise men among the idolaters, especially the baksi, have represented to his majesty, that to provide for the poor is a good work and highly grateful to their deities, he has bestowed charity in the manner now described, so that, at his court, none are denied food who come to ask for it.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: He has also so arranged that in all the highways by which messengers, merchants, and other persons travel, trees are planted at short distances on both sides of the road, and are so tall that they can be seen from a great distance.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: They serve thus both to show the way and afford a grateful shade.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: This is done whenever the nature of the soil admits of plantation ;

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: but when the route lies through sandy deserts or over rocky mountains, he has ordered stones to be set up, or columns erected, to guide the traveller.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: Officers of rank are appointed, whose duty it is to take care that these matters be properly arranged, and the roads kept constantly in good order.

sectionTitle: The Care and Bounty of the Monarch towards his Subjects
sentence: Besides other motives, the great khan is influenced by the declaration of his soothsayers and astrologers, that those who plant trees receive long life as their reward.

sectionTitle: Liquor used for Wine in Cathay
sentence: You must know that the greater part of the people of Cathay drink a wine made of rice and many good spices, and prepare it in such a way that it is more agreeable to drink than any other liquid.

sectionTitle: Liquor used for Wine in Cathay
sentence: It is clear and beautiful, and it makes a man drunk sooner than any other wine, for it is extremely hot.

sectionTitle: Stones which are burnt instead of Wood
sentence: It may be observed, also, that throughout the whole province of Cathay, there are a kind of black stones cut from the mountains in veins, which burn like logs.

sectionTitle: Stones which are burnt instead of Wood
sentence: They maintain the fire better than wood.

sectionTitle: Stones which are burnt instead of Wood
sentence: If you put them on in the evening, they will preserve it the whole night, and will be found burning in the morning.

sectionTitle: Stones which are burnt instead of Wood
sentence: Throughout the whole of Cathay this fuel is used.

sectionTitle: Stones which are burnt instead of Wood
sentence: They have also wood indeed ;

sectionTitle: Stones which are burnt instead of Wood
sentence: but the stones are much less expensive.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: The city of Kambalu contains, inclusive of Christians, Saracens, and Kataians, about 5000 astrologers and soothsayers, whom the emperor provides with food and clothing, as he does the poor families;

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: and they are constantly practising their art.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: They have astrolabes, on which are delineated the planetary signs, the hours of passing the meridian, and their successive aspects during the whole year.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: The astrologers of each separate sect annually examine their respective tables, to ascertain thence the course of the heavenly bodies, and their relative positions for every lunation.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: From the paths and configurations of the planets in the several signs, they foretell the state of the weather and the peculiar phenomena which are to occur in each month.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: In one, for instance, there will be thunder and storms; in another earthquakes; in a third violent lightning and rain ; in a fourth pestilence, mortality, war, discord, conspiracy.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: What they find in their astrolabes they predict, adding, however, that God may at his pleasure do either more or less than they have announced.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: Their annual prophecies are written on small squares called takuini, which are sold at a moderate price to all persons anxious to search into futurity.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: Those whose announcements prove more generally correct are accounted the most perfect masters of their art, and consequently held in the highest honour.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: When any one projects a great work, a long journey for commercial purposes, or any other undertaking, the probable success of which he is desirous to learn, he goes to one of these astrologers, informs him of the time at which he intends to set out, and inquires what aspect the heavens then exhibit.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: The astrologer replies, that before he can answer, he must be informed of the year, month, and hour of his nativity, on learning which he examines how the constellation that was then in the ascendant corresponds with the aspect of the celestial bodies at the time of the inquiry.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: Upon this comparison he founds his prediction as to the favourable or unfavourable issue of the enterprise.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: The Tartars compute time by a cycle of twelve years, the first of which they name the lion ; the second, the ox; the third, the dragon ; the fourth, the dog; and so on till all the twelve have elapsed.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: When any one,therefore, is asked the year in which he was born, he answers, it was in that of the lion, on such a day, and at such an hour and minute;

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: all of which had been carefully noted in a book.

sectionTitle: The Astrologers of Kambalu-the Tartar Computation of Time
sentence: When the years of the cycle are completed, they begin again with the first, and constantly go over the same round.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: These people are idolaters, and each person has, for the object of worship, a tablet fixed against an elevated part of the wall of his apartment, having a name written on it which denotes the high, heavenly, and mighty God, and this they daily worship, burning incense before it.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: Raising their hands, and beating their faces three times against the floor, they entreat from him the blessings of sound understanding and bodily health, addressing no other petition.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: Below, on the floor, they have a statue named Natigai, considered as the god of terrestrial objects, or of whatever is produced on the earth.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: They suppose him to have a wife and children, and worship him in the same manner with incense, lifting their hands, and bending to the ground.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: They pray to him for good weather, plentiful crops, increase of family, and other such objects, They believe the soul to be so far immortal, that immediately after death it enters another body, and according as a man�s actions in this life have been virtuous or wicked, his future state will be progressively more or less fortunate.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: If he has been poor, yet acted worthily and respectably, he will be born anew, first of a lady, becoming himself a gentleman ; then of a woman of rank, becoming a nobleman, and he will continually ascend in the scale of existence till he becomes united with the divinity.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: Onthe contrary, if a gentleman's son have acted unworthily, he will, at his next birth, become a clown, and at length a dog ; descending always to a condition more vile than the former.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: They converse courteously, accosting each other with politeness and with countenances expressive of pleasure ;

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: they have a well-bred air, and a manner of eating particularly cleanly.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: The utmost reverence is shown to parents ;

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: and should any child treat his with disrespect, or neglect to assist them, there is a public tribunal having for its especial object to punish the crime of -filial ingratitude.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: Malefactors, when found guilty, after being apprehended and thrown into prison, are strangled ;

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: but such as remain till the expiry of three years, a time appointed by his majesty for a general release, are set at liberty, having however a brand fixed on one of the cheeks, by which they may be recognised.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: The great khan has prohibited all gambling and other species of fraud, to which this people are addicted beyond any other upon earth;

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: and as a reason for this prohibition, he tells them in his edict, " I subdued you by the power of my sword, and consequently whatever you possess belongs of right to me; in gambling, therefore, you sport with my property."

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: Yet he does not, by the right thus claimed, take any thing on an arbitrary principle.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: The orderly and regular manner in which all ranks present themselves before him deserves notice.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: On approaching within half a mile of his residence, they testify their reverence for his exalted rank by an humble, subdued, and quiet demeanour, so that not the least noise is heard, nor does any one call, or even speak aloud.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: Every man of rank carries with him, while he continues in the hall of audience, a vessel into which he spits, that he may not soil the floor;

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: and having done so, he replaces the cover, and makes a bow.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: They usually take with them handsome buskins of white leather, and on reaching the court, before entering the hall, where they wait to be summoned by his majesty, put them on, giving those worn in walking to the care of the servants.

sectionTitle: Religion and Customs of the Tartars (Chinese)
sentence: This precaution is taken that they may not sully the beautiful carpets, curiously wrought with silk and gold, and exhibiting a variety of colours.

sectionTitle: Marco Polo's Journey-The River Pulisangan and its beautiful Bridge
sentence: I have now to inform you that the great khan having sent Messer Marco as his ambassador into the western provinces, he departed from Kambalu, and travelled in that direction full four months.

sectionTitle: Marco Polo's Journey-The River Pulisangan and its beautiful Bridge
sentence: You shall now hear all that he saw on that journey going and returning.

sectionTitle: Marco Polo's Journey-The River Pulisangan and its beautiful Bridge
sentence: When a man leaves Kambalu and has gone ten miles, he finds a river called Pulisangan, which flows on to the ocean, and is crossed by many merchants with their goods.

sectionTitle: Marco Polo's Journey-The River Pulisangan and its beautiful Bridge
sentence: Over it is a grand stone bridge, which has not its equal in the world ;

sectionTitle: Marco Polo's Journey-The River Pulisangan and its beautiful Bridge
sentence: it is 300 paces long and eight broad, and ten horsemen can ride abreast over it.

sectionTitle: Marco Polo's Journey-The River Pulisangan and its beautiful Bridge
sentence: It has twenty-four arches, supported by piers in the water, and is wholly of marble, finely wrought into columns in the manner that I will tell you.

sectionTitle: Marco Polo's Journey-The River Pulisangan and its beautiful Bridge
sentence: At the head of the bridge is a column of marble, above and beneath which are beautifully carved lions of the same material, and about a pace distant is another column, with its lions, and between the two are slabs of gray marble, to secure passengers from falling into the water ;

sectionTitle: Marco Polo's Journey-The River Pulisangan and its beautiful Bridge
sentence: and the whole bridge thus formed is the most magnificent object in the world.

sectionTitle: The great City of Geo-gui
sentence: After leaving that bridge a man travels thirty miles westward, finding every where fine trees, villages, and inns, and then comes to a city which is named Geo-gui.

sectionTitle: The great City of Geo-gui
sentence: The country is rich in grain, the people are all idolaters ;

sectionTitle: The great City of Geo-gui
sentence: they live by merchandise and the arts, making cloth of gold, as well as silk, and beautiful linen.

sectionTitle: The great City of Geo-gui
sentence: There are also numerous houses for the reception of strangers.

sectionTitle: The great City of Geo-gui
sentence: A mile beyond that city are two roads, one leading westward through Cathay, the other southward to the great province of Manji.

sectionTitle: The great City of Geo-gui
sentence: In riding westward through Cathay full ten days, you find always handsome cities and castles, abundance of arts and merchandise, fine inns, trees, vines, and a civilized people.

sectionTitle: The Cities of Ta-in-fu and Pi-an-fu
sentence: At the end of this journey is a kingdom named Ta-in-fu,with a capital of the same name.

sectionTitle: The Cities of Ta-in-fu and Pi-an-fu
sentence: It contains many arts and much merchandise, with a large supply of stores necessary for the imperial army.

sectionTitle: The Cities of Ta-in-fu and Pi-an-fu
sentence: The district presents numerous vineyards, and being the only part of Cathay where wine is made, supplies it to the surrounding provinces.

sectionTitle: The Cities of Ta-in-fu and Pi-an-fu
sentence: It yields also much silk, abounding in the trees on which the worms are fed.

sectionTitle: The Cities of Ta-in-fu and Pi-an-fu
sentence: A degree of civilisation prevails among all the people of this country, in consequence of their frequent intercourse with the numerous towns which lie very near each other.

sectionTitle: The Cities of Ta-in-fu and Pi-an-fu
sentence: The merchants are constantly carrying their goods from one to another, as fairs are successively held at each.

sectionTitle: The Cities of Ta-in-fu and Pi-an-fu
sentence: Five days' journey beyond the ten already mentioned, there is said to be another city still larger and handsomer, named Achbaluch, where are the limits of his majesty's hunting-ground, within which no person must sport, except princes of his family, and others whose names are inscribed on the grand falconer's list ;

sectionTitle: The Cities of Ta-in-fu and Pi-an-fu
sentence: beyond, all persons qualified by their rank have that liberty.

sectionTitle: The Cities of Ta-in-fu and Pi-an-fu
sentence: The khan scarcely ever follows the chase in this quarter;

sectionTitle: The Cities of Ta-in-fu and Pi-an-fu
sentence: hence the wild animals, especially hares, multiply to such a degree, as to cause the destruction of all the growing corn.

sectionTitle: The Cities of Ta-in-fu and Pi-an-fu
sentence: This having come to his knowledge, he was induced to repair thither with his whole court, and prodigious quantities of game were then taken.

sectionTitle: The Cities of Ta-in-fu and Pi-an-fu
sentence: Leaving Ta-in-fu, and riding westward full seven days through very fine districts, amid numerous merchants, you find a large town, named Pi-an-fu,supported by commerce and the silk manufacture.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: Two miles west of Pi-an-fu is a famous castle, named Caya-fu,built anciently by a king named Dor.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: In this castle is a very beautiful palace, with a great hall, containing portraits, beautifully painted, of all the kings who formerly reigned in these provinces.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: Having mentioned this King Dor, I will tell you a curious story of what passed between him and Prester John.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: The two sovereigns being at war, Dor was in so strong a situation that the other could not reach him, and was therefore much chagrined ;

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: upon which seven of his servants said that they would bring before him his adversary, and if he wished even alive.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: He said he should be very much obliged to them.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: Having obtained this permission, they went to the king and presented themselves as strangers desirous to serve him.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: He gave them an honourable welcome, and they began their duties with the utmost zeal, rendering themselves extremely acceptable.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: After they had remained two years, he became greatly attached to them, and confided in their love as if they had been his sons.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: Now hear what these wicked fellows did, and how difficult it is to find defence against a traitor.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: The king happened to go out on an excursion with a small number of persons, among whom were these seven.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: When they had passed a river distant from the palace, seeing that the king had not attendants enough to defend him, they laid hands on him, drew their swords, and threatened to kill him unless he instantly went along with them.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: He was greatly surprised, and said to them,-"What mean you by this, my sons? -what are you saying-whither do you wish me to go?"

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: They replied :-" We wish you to come with us to Prester John, who is our master."

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: When Dor heard this, he almost died with grief, and said-" ha!my good friends, have I not honoured and treated you as children; why will you betray me into the hands of my enemy? This would be a most wicked and disloyal action."

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: They replied that it must be so.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: They led him to their sovereign, who rejoiced greatly, and addressed the king in very rough language.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: He made no reply, not knowing what to answer; upon which, the other set him to keep his cattle, as a mark of disgrace and contempt, and during two years he performed this menial office.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: After that time Prester John was appeased, and resolved to spare his captive.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: He bestowed on him splendid regal vestments, paying him great honour, and saying," Now own you were not a man capable of making war against me."

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: The king then replied,-"Sire, I always knew that I was unable to contend with you; I repent much of my former bad conduct, and promise faithfully that I will always be your friend."

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: Then said the christian prince,-" I will impose upon you no more hardship and grief; you shall receive favour and honour."

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: Having then supplied him with many horses handsomely equipped, and a numerous attendance, he permitted him to go.

sectionTitle: The Castle of Caya-fu--Story of its King and Prester John
sentence: Dor then returned to his kingdom, and from that time was a faithful friend and servant of Prester John.

sectionTitle: The great River Kara-moran, and the City Ca-cian-fu
sentence: Twenty miles westward from that castle is a river called Kara-moran,so large and broad that it cannot be crossed by a bridge, and flows on even to the ocean.

sectionTitle: The great River Kara-moran, and the City Ca-cian-fu
sentence: On its banks are many cities and castles, likewise many merchants and manufactured goods;

sectionTitle: The great River Kara-moran, and the City Ca-cian-fu
sentence: and in the country around ginger grows in great abundance.

sectionTitle: The great River Kara-moran, and the City Ca-cian-fu
sentence: The number of birds is wonderful, so that for a Venetian grosso one can buy three pheasants ;

sectionTitle: The great River Kara-moran, and the City Ca-cian-fu
sentence: and after travelling three days, you find a noble city named Ca-cian-fu.

sectionTitle: The great River Kara-moran, and the City Ca-cian-fu
sentence: The people are idolaters, as likewise those of Cathay.

sectionTitle: The great River Kara-moran, and the City Ca-cian-fu
sentence: It is a city of great merchandise and many arts.

sectionTitle: The great River Kara-moran, and the City Ca-cian-fu
sentence: They have abundance of silk, with cloth of gold of all fashions.

sectionTitle: The great River Kara-moran, and the City Ca-cian-fu
sentence: I will go on to tell you of the capital of the kingdom.

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: When a man has left the city of Ca-cian-fu, and travelled eight days westward, he finds always cities and castles, merchandise and arts, pleasure-grounds and houses;

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: and the whole country is full of mulberries, producing abundance of silk.

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: The men are idolaters and live by labouring the ground, hunting, and hawking.

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: At the end of the eight days he comes to the noble city of Quen-gian-fu,capital of a kingdom anciently magnificent and powerful, and which had many noble and valiant kings.

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: At present the crown is held by Mangalu, a son of the great khan.

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: That city is rich in merchandise and manufactures, particularly of implements for the supply of an army;

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: likewise every thing necessary for the subsistence of man.

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: The people are all idolaters.

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: Westward is a beautiful palace of King Mangalu, which I will describe to you.

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: It lies in a great plain watered by a river, as also by many lakes and fountains.

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: A wall five miles in circuit, surrounded with battlements, and well built, encloses this splendid edifice, having halls and chambers adorned with beaten gold.

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: Mangalu exercises his dominion with great justice, and is much beloved by his people ;

sectionTitle: The City of Quen-gian-fu
sentence: the residents in the district enjoy great amusement in hawking and hunting.

sectionTitle: The Province of Cun-chin
sentence: A man departing from this palace travels three days west ward through a very fine plain, always finding villages and castles, with men living by merchandise and rearing silk in great abundance.

sectionTitle: The Province of Cun-chin
sentence: He then comes to great mountains and valleys belonging to the province of Cun-chin ;the people are all idolaters, and subsist by agriculture and hunting, having many forests full of various wild animals.

sectionTitle: The Province of Cun-chin
sentence: Thus a man rides for twenty days through mountains, valleys, and woods, always finding cities, castles, and good inns.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: After this journey, he enters a province named Achalech-Manji, entirely level, and full of cities and castles.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: The people are all idolaters, and live by merchandise and art, and the province yields such a quantity of ginger, that it is distributed throughout Cathay, to the great profit of the inhabitants.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: The land also yields rice, wheat, and other grain, and is rich in all productions.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: The principal country is called Achalech-Manji, which means in our language one of the borders of Manji.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: This plain lasts for two days, and we then travel twenty through mountains, valleys, and woods, seeing many cities and castles.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: These people are idolaters, and live on the fruits of the earth and the flesh of birds and beasts;

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: for there are abundance of lions, bears, wolves, stags, deer, and particularly of those animals which yield the musk.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: When a man has left this country and travelled twenty days westward, he approaches a province on the borders of Manji named Sin-din-fu.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: The capital, bearing the same name, was anciently very great and noble, governed by a mighty and wealthy sovereign.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: He died, leaving three sons, who divided the city into three parts, and each enclosed his portion with a wall, which was within the great wall of twenty miles in circuit.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: They ranked still as kings, and had ample possessions ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: but the great khan overcame them, and took full possession of their territory.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: Through the city, a large river of fresh water, abounding with fish, passes and flows on to the ocean, distant eighty or a hundred days' journey ; it is called Quian-su.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: On that current is a very great number of cities and castles, and such a multitude of ships, as no one who has not seen could possibly believe.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: Equally wonderful is the quantity of merchandise conveyed ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: indeed it is so broad as to appear a sea and not a river.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: Within the city, it is crossed by a bridge, wholly of marble, half a mile long and eight paces broad ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: the upper part is supported by marble columns, and richly painted ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: and upon it are many houses where merchants expose goods for sale ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: but these are set up in the morning and taken down in the evening.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: At one of them, larger than the others, stands the chamberlain of the khan, who receives the duty on the merchandise sold, which is worth annually a thousand golden bezants.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: The inhabitants are all idolaters ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: and from that city a man goes five days' journey through castles, villages, and scattered houses.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: The people subsist by agriculture, and the tract abounds with wild beasts.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: There are also large manufactures of gauzes and cloth of gold.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: After travelling these five days, he comes to Thibet.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: This is a very large province;

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: the men have a language of their own, and are idolaters.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: They border upon Manji and many other countries, and are very great robbers ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: the extent is such, that it contains eight kingdoms and many cities and castles.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: There are also extensive rivers, lakes, and mountains, where is found a vast quantity of gold.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: Cinnamon and coral occur, which last is very dear, because they place it round the neck of their women and their idols, and hold it as a precious jewel.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: Here are made camlets, and other cloths of silk and gold.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: There are very skilful enchanters and astrologers, but extremely wicked men, who perform works of the devil, which it were unlawful to relate, they would strike with such amazement.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: They have mastiff dogs as largeas asses, and excellent in taking wild animals.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: This province was entirely destroyed by Mangou, the fifth great khan, in his wars;

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: and its many villages and castles are all demolished.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: Here grow large canes, fifteen paces long and four palms thick, while from one knot to the other is full three palms.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: The merchants and travellers, who pass through that country in the night, take these canes and set them on fire, when they make such a loud crackling noise that lions, bears, and other destructive animals are terrified, and dare not approach.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: They also split them in the middle, and produce thus so mighty a sound, that it would be heard in the night at the distance of five miles ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: and the explosion is so alarming, that horses unaccustomed to it often break their reins and harness, and take to flight.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: For this reason, travellers, riding such horses, bind them by the feet, and stop their eyes and ears.

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: A man travels twenty days through these countries without finding either inns or victuals;

sectionTitle: The Province of Achalech-Manji
sentence: he must therefore carry with him food for himself and his cattle during the whole of that space, meeting always, too, ferocious wild beasts, which are very dangerous.

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: The traveller then comes to a part of Thibet where there are houses and castles;

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: but the people have a bad custom.

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: None of them for the whole world will marry a virtuous maiden, saying that she is worth nothing without having had many lovers.

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: When strangers, therefore, pass through, and have pitched their tents, or taken their lodging in inns, the old women bring their daughters, often to the number of thirty or forty, and offer them as wives during their stay ;

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: but they must not carry them thence, either back or forward.

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: When the merchant is about to depart, he gives to the lady some toy or jewel as a testimony that she has lived with him.

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: These jewels she hangs to her neck, and is anxious to have at least twenty ;

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: for the more she can show, the higher is she valued, and the more readily obtains a husband.

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: After being married, she is strictly watched, and any infidelity is deeply resented.

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: These people are idolatrous and wicked, not holding it sinful to commit wrong and robbery ;

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: in short, they are the greatest thieves in the world.

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: They live on the fruits of the earth, but mostly by hunting and falconry ;

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: and the country contains many of those animals which produce musk, and are called in the Tartar language gudderi.

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: That sinful people have many good dogs,which they employ in the pursuit of wild animals.

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: They have neither the cards nor money circulated by the great khan, but make money of salt.

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: They are poorly clad with the skins of beasts, canvass, and buckram ;

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: they have a language of their own, which they call Tebet.

sectionTitle: Another Part of Thibet
sentence: Now I will tell you of Kain-du.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: This is a province lying to the west, having only one king, the inhabitants idolaters, and subject to the great khan.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: It contains a number of cities and castles, with a lake, in which are found many pearls;

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: but the monarch forbids them, under a severe penalty, to be removed except for his own use ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: because, if any one were allowed to take them, they would become worth almost nothing.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: There is also a mountain, whence are quarried turquoise stones in great abundance, very large and beautiful ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: but he does not allow them to be removed unless by his mandate.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: In this province they have a strange and base custom, that a man thinks there is no disgrace in an improper intimacy between his wife or sister and a stranger or other person.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: On the contrary, when such a one comes to reside in his house, the master presently goes out, and leaves him with his wife.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: The visiter remains often three days, and places a hat or something else at the window as a signal;

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: and the husband never returns till he sees this taken away.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: This is said to be done in honour of their idols, who on that account bestow on them many blessings.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: Their gold is in small rods,-the value being determined according to the weight, and not marked by any stamp.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: The small money is thus made: they take salt, form it into a shape, so that it weighs about half a pound, and eighty of these are worth a rod of gold.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: They have a very great number of the animals which yield the musk ; likewise fishes from the same lake whence the pearls are drawn ; also the usual kinds of wild birds and beasts.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: No wine is obtained from vines, but it is made from grain or rice with many spices, which makes a good liquor.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: In that province also grows a tree called garofol;

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: it is small, with leaves like a laurel, but longer and narrower ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: it bears a small white flower.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: It yields ginger, cinnamon, and other spices, which come into our country ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: but I have now said to you enough of Kain-du.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: After travelling ten days you come to a river which bounds it, named Brius.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: In it is found a great quantity of gold dust ; and on its banks abundance of cinnamon ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: it flows on to the ocean.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kain-du
sentence: Now let us tell you of Caraian.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: When a man has departed and crossed the river, he enters this province, which is large, and contains seven kingdoms extending westward.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: The people are all idolaters, and under the dominion of the great khan.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: The king is a son of his, named Essetemur, and is great, rich, and powerful.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: He is also brave and upright, ruling his country with much justice.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: When the traveller has crossed the river, he passes, during a journey of five days, through a country where there is abundance of cities and castles, with many very good horses ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: and the people are supported by cattle and the produce of land.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: Their language is extremely difficult to understand.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: At the end of these five days, he comes to the capital of the country, named Yaci, which is particularly great and noble, with many merchants and numerous arts.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: There are here various sects, Saracens, idolaters, and Nestorian Christians.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: There is a good deal of grain and rice, yet the country is not very fertile.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: They make a drink of the latter which intoxicates like wine.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: Money is formed of porcelain, such as is found in the sea,and eighty pieces are worth one bar of gold, or eight of silver.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: They have pits whence they draw vast quantities of salt, from which the king derives a great revenue.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: Adultery is not considered as a crime, unless when accompanied with violence.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: There is a lake here extending a hundred miles, and containing many large fishes, the best in the world.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: They use the raw flesh of all fowls and beasts ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: for the poor people go to the market and get it newly taken from the animal, put it in garlic sauce, then eat it;

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: the rich likewise eat it raw, but previously cut into small pieces, and the sauce mixed with good spices.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: When a man leaves Yaci, or Chiaci, and goes ten days westward, he finds the province of Karazan, with a capital of the same name.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: The people are all idolaters, and subject to the great khan;

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: the king is a son of that monarch, named Kogatin.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: Gold dust is found in the river, and on the mountains in large pieces so abundantly that a bar is given for six of silver.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: The porcelain, too, formerly described circulates for money, but is procured from India.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: Here are snakes and serpents so huge as to strike all men with astonishment;

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: they are ten paces long, ten palms broad, and have no feet, but only a hoof like that of the lion;

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: the nose is like a loaf of bread, the mouth so huge that it would swallow at once a man whole;

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: the teeth are immense, nor is there any wild beast whom they do not strike with terror.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: There are smaller ones eight paces long and six palms broad.

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: The mode of catching them is this :-They remain during the day in great caverns under the earth, to avoid the heat, but at night go out to feed, and seize all the animals whom they can reach;

sectionTitle: The Province of Caraian
sentence: they also seek drink at the rivers, fountains, and lakes, and then make a deep track in the sand, as if a barrel had been dragged through it.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: In it the people fix a stake, fasten to it a steel instrument sharpened like a razor, and cover it over with sand.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: When the serpent comes through the track, and strikes against the steel, he is pierced with such violence, that his body is divided from one side to the other, as high as the umbilical cord, and he presently dies.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: They then take the body and extract the gall-bladder, which they sell very dear, being an excellent medicine for the bite of a mad dog, when administered in small dozes.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: It is also valuable in childbirth, and when given to the woman, a safe delivery immmediately follows.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: The flesh also is sold at a high price, being considered delicate food.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: The serpent also enters the dens of lions, bears, and other fierce animals, and devours their whelps, when he can get at them.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: Here, too, are very large horses, which are carried into India to be sold.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: They cut two or three nerves from the tail, so that they may not strike with it the man who rides, which is considered disgraceful.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: These people ride like the French, with long staffs, have arms covered with buffalo hide, and carry lances, spears, and poisoned arrows.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: Before the great khan conquered them they had a wicked custom, that when any stranger came to lodge with them who was agreeable, wise, and opulent, they killed him during the night by poison or some other mode.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: This was not out of enmity or with the view of taking his money, but because they imagined that his wisdom and other good qualities would thus remain with them.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: However, about thirty-five years ago, after that monarch conquered the country, he prohibited this crime, which, from fear of him, they no longer commit.

sectionTitle: The Province of Karazan and its great Serpents
sentence: Now let us tell of another province called Kardandan.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: When a man departs from Karazan, and travels to the westward, he enters a province named Kardandan, inhabited by idolaters, and subject to the great khan.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: The chief city is called Vociam.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: All the people have their teeth, both upper and lower, covered with gold, which thus appear to be made of that metal.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: The men are soldiers, and regard nothing but war;

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: the women, with the slaves, perform all the work.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: When any lady has been delivered of a boy, the husband goes to bed, taking the child with him, and remains there forty days.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: He thus allows rest to the mother, who is only obliged to suckle the infant.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: All his friends then come and make a festival, when the wife rises, manages the domestic affairs, and serves her husband, still lying in bed.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: They eat all kinds of flesh, both raw and cooked, and rice dressed along with it, and make a very good wine of rice and spices.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: They have money of gold and porcelain, and give a bar of gold for five of silver, having no mines of the latter metal within five days' distance ;

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: by this exchange the merchants make great profit.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: This people have neither idols nor churches, but adore the master of the house, and say of him, "we are his; and he is our god."

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: They have neither letters nor writing, which is not wonderful, because they live in an unfrequented place, that cannot be visited in the summer on account of the air, which is then so corrupted and pestilent that no foreigner can live there.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: Whenever they have dealings together, they select a piece of timber, square or round, cleave it in the middle, and each takes a half;

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: this must be done before two, three, or four witnesses.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: When the payment comes to be made, the one receives the money and gives his half of the wood.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: In all those provinces there is no physician, but when any one is sick, doctors and exorcists of evil spirits are sent for, who, on coming to the patient, begin their incantations, beating instruments, singing and dancing.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: In a short time one of them falls to the ground, foams at the mouth, and becomes half-dead, when the devil enters into his body.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: The other magicians then ask the half-dead man what is the cause of the patient's illness.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: The demon answers from his mouth that the sufferer has given displeasure to such or such a spirit, who is therefore tormenting him.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: Then if the sick man is to die, the fiend in the body of the magician says, -"the spirit has been wronged and displeased to such a degree, that he will not spare him for any thing in the world."

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: They then say, "we beseech you to pardon him, and take in compensation for his blood the presents which we now exhibit."

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: If on the contrary a cure is to take place, the devil from the body says, " take so many sheep and so many dishes of rich pottage, and make a sacrifice of them to the angry spirit."

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: The relations of the patient do every thing thus ordered, killing the sheep, sprinkling the blood, and preparing the dishes of pottage.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: A great assemblage is made of men and women, who hold a joyous feast, dancing and singing songs in praise of the spirit.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: They burn incense and myrrh, with which they fumigate and illuminate the whole house.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: When they have acted thus for about an hour, the first magician again falls down, and they inquire if the sick man is now pardoned and will be cured.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: It is then answered that he is not yet pardoned, but something more must be done, after which forgiveness will be granted.

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: This order is obeyed, when he says, "he is pardoned, and will be immediately cured".

sectionTitle: The Province of Kardandan
sentence: The company then exclaim,"the spirit is on our side," and having eaten the sheep and drunk the pottage with great joy and festivity, they return to their homes.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: Now I must mention a very great battle which was fought in the kingdom of Vociam, and you shall hear all how it happened.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: In the year of our Lord 1272, the great khan sent a mighty captain, named Nescardin, with 12,000 men, to defend the province of Caraian.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: He was a prudent man, very strong in arms and skilful in war ;

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: and the soldiers with him were good and very brave warriors.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: Now the King of Mien and of Bangala were afraid lest he should invade their territory ;

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: yet they thought they were able to overcome and destroy the whole army in such a manner that the great khan might never feel inclined to send another into the same quarter.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: They assembled, therefore, 60,000 horse and foot, with 2000 elephants, each of which had on its back a castle well fortified and defended by twelve, fourteen, or sixteen men.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: The King of Mien came with the above army to the city of Vociam, where was the array of the Tartars, and took post in a plain at the distance of three days' journey.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: Nescardin was somewhat alarmed, considering how small a force he had in comparison with the host of the King of Mien;

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: but he took courage, reflecting that his troops were brave and most valiant warriors.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: He therefore marched to meet them in the plain of Vociam, and pitched his camp near a great forest, filled with lofty trees, into which he was aware that elephants could not enter.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: The King of Mien, seeing the army of Nescardin, advanced to attack it.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: The Tartars went with great boldness to meet them, but when their horses saw the elephants with the wooden castles upon them, stationed and arranged in the first line, they were struck with such terror that the riders could not, either by force or any contrivance, make them approach.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: They, therefore, immediately alighted, and tied them to the trees, when the infantry returned to the line of elephants, and began to discharge their arrows with the utmost violence.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: Those who were on the backs of the animals fought bravely;

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: but the Tartars were stronger, and more accustomed to battle.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: They wounded very severely with these missiles a multitude of the elephants, which, being terrified, took to flight and rushed with violence into the adjacent wood.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: As they could not be restrained from entering, and rushing backward and forward through the thick trees in confusion, they broke the wooden castles on their backs, and destroyed all their equipments.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: When the Tartars saw these animals disposed of, they ran to their horses, which were bound to the trees, mounted them, and rushed upon the warriors of the King of Mien.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: They began the attack with a shower of arrows, but as the king and his troops still defended themselves valiantly, they drew their swords, and rushed into close combat.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: Now mighty blows were struck ; swords and spears were fiercely thrust on both sides ; heads, arms, and hands were struck off ;

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: and many warriors fell to the earth dead and dying.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: The noise and cries would have drowned the loudest thunder.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: At length, after midday, the host of Mien gave way;

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: and the king, with all who survived the battle, took to flight, pursued by the Tartars, who killed many of the fugitives.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: When satisfied with pursuit, they returned to the wood to catch the elephants.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: They endeavoured to stop the flight of these animals by cutting down the trees and laying them across;

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: yet they are so intelligent, that the soldiers would not have succeeded but for the aid of some of the captives taken in battle, through whose means they were able to recover two hundred.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: From this time the great khan began to employ elephants in his army, which he had not hither to done.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: Afterwards that monarch conquered the lands of Mien, and added them to his dominion.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: When you have departed from the said province of Caraian, there begins a great descent, which continues for two days and a half;

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: and in all this journey nothing occurs worthy of notice, except that there is a great space in which a market is held on certain days of the year.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: Thither come many merchants from divers countries and districts, some of whom bring gold and silver to exchange ;

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: and they give an ounce of the former for five of the latter.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: None but those who bring the gold can penetrate into the countries where it is produced, so difficult and intricate are the roads.

sectionTitle: Of the great Battle fought between the Tartars and the King of Mien
sentence: When a man has travelled these two days and a half, he comes to a district which is called Anniz, on the borders of India, towards the south, and then he goes for fifteen days through a region covered with woods filled with elephants, unicorns, and other savage beasts, but not containing any human habitation.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: At the termination of these wild and pathless tracts is a large and noble city called Mien, the capital of the province.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: The people are all idolaters, with a language peculiar to themselves, and are subject to the great khan.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: About this city I will tell you a thing very remarkable.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: There was anciently in it a rich and powerful king, who, being about to die, commanded that on his tomb should be erected two towers, one of gold, and the other of silver.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: They are full ten paces high, and of a suitable thickness ;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: the first, being composed of stone, is covered all over with gold to the thickness of a finger, so that to the spectator it appears wholly of that metal.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: The summit is round, and filled with little golden bells, which the wind, whenever it strikes them, causes to ring.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: The other tower is similarly formed, but is coated with silver, and has silver bells.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: By these buildings the king intentled to display his greatness and dignity, and they are the most beautiful and valuable to be seen in the world.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: Between them he caused the sepulchre to be constructed, where he is now buried.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: When the great khan conquered that city, he desired all the players and buffoons, of whom there were a great number in his court, to go and achieve the conquest, offering them a captain and some warlike aid.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: The jesters willingly undertook the affair, and setting out with the proffered assistance, subdued this province of Mien.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: When they came to that noble city, and saw these splendid edifices, they admired exceedingly, and sent to the great khan an account of their beauty, and of the manner in which they were constructed, asking if he wished them to be demolished, and the gold and silver sent to him.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: The monarch, on hearing this, commanded that they should not be destroyed, since the king had erected them to commemorate his greatness, and no Tartar touches any thing belonging to a dead man.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: They were therefore to continue in the same condition as they now stood.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: This province contains elephants, wild oxen large and beautiful, stags, deer, and other animals.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Mien, and the most beautiful Tomb of the the King
sentence: Now, let me tell you of another which is called Bangala.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Bangala
sentence: This is a province towards the south, which, in the year 1290, while I, Marco, was at the court of the great khan, was not yet conquered, but the army was there, ready to march for that purpose.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Bangala
sentence: It has a king and languages of its own, and the people are most wicked idolaters.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Bangala
sentence: They are on the confines of India.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Bangala
sentence: The barons and lords of that country have oxen as tall as elephants, but not so weighty ; and live on flesh and rice.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Bangala
sentence: They have great abundance of silk, with which they carry on extensive manufactures ; also ginger, sugar, and many other costly spices.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Bangala
sentence: This place is visited by numerous merchants, who purchase slaves, make them eunuchs, and then either sell or convey them to other places.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Kangigu
sentence: Kangigu is a province towards the east, subject to a king;

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Kangigu
sentence: the people are all idolaters; have a language of their own ; and owning the supremacy of the great khan, they pay him an annual tribute.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Kangigu
sentence: The king is so luxurious as to have 300 wives, for as soon as he hears of a beautiful woman in the country he takes her to himself.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Kangigu
sentence: The people have much gold and many precious spices ;

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Kangigu
sentence: but being far from the sea, their commodities do not bring the full value.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Kangigu
sentence: They have many elephants and beasts of various other kinds.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Kangigu
sentence: All the men and women paint their bodies, the colours being worked in with the claws of lions, dragons, and eagles, and thus never effaced.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Kangigu
sentence: In this manner they stain their neck, breast, hands, limbs, and indeed their whole person.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Kangigu
sentence: This is considered extremely genteel, and the more any one is painted, the higher is his rank considered.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Kangigu
sentence: Now let us tell you of another province named Amu.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Amu
sentence: Amu is also a province towards the east, subject to the great khan.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Amu
sentence: The people are idolaters, live by pasturage and agriculture, and have a language of their own.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Amu
sentence: The ladies wear on their arms and legs valuable bracelets of gold and silver, and the men have these still finer and rarer.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Amu
sentence: They have good horses in considerable numbers, many of which the Indians purchase and sell again to much advantage.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Amu
sentence: They have also abundance of oxen and buffaloes, because they have extensive and good pastures;

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Amu
sentence: in short, they have plenty of the means of subsistence.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Amu
sentence: From Amu to Kangigu, are fifteen days, and thence to Bangala, which is the third province behind, are thirty days.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Amu
sentence: Now let us come to another province, which is called Tholoman, and lies eight journeys from this to the east.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Tholoman
sentence: Tholoman is a third province towards the east.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Tholoman
sentence: All the - people are idolaters, have a language of their own, and are under the great khan.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Tholoman
sentence: They are handsome, of rather a brown complexion, good men at arms, and have a number of cities, castles, and forts, on the top of very high mountains.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Tholoman
sentence: When they die, the bodies are burned, and the bones which cannot be consumed are placed in chests and carried to the caverns of high mountains, where they are kept suspended, so that neither man nor beast can touch them.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Tholoman
sentence: Gold is found here ;

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Tholoman
sentence: but the small money is of porcelain, which circulates in all these provinces.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Tholoman
sentence: The merchants, though few, are rich ;

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Tholoman
sentence: the people live on flesh and rice, and have many good spices.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: Cyn-gui is a province likewise situated towards the east, and when a man leaves Tholoman, he goes twelve days along a river, where there are towns and castles, but nothing else worth mentioning.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: At the end of these twelve days, he finds the city Sinugul, very large and noble.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: The inhabitants are all idolaters, and subject to the great khan.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: They live by merchandise and arts, and weave cloths of the bark of trees, which make fine summer dresses.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: They are good men at arms ;

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: but they have no money except paper.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: There are in this country so many lions, that if a man were to sleep out of doors, he would presently be killed and eaten by them;

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: and at night, when a bark sails along the river, if it were not kept at a good distance from the bank, they would rush in and carry off the crew.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: However, though these animals be so large and dangerous, the natives have a wonderful manner of defending themselves;

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: for the dogs of that country are so daring, that they will assault a large one, and, seconded by a man, will kill him.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: I will tell you how: when a man is on horseback with two of these dogs, as soon as they see a lion, they throw themselves behind him, and bite his thighs and body.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: The lion turns furiously round, but they wheel about with him so swiftly, that he cannot reach them.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: He then retreats till he comes to a tree, against which he places his back, and turns his face to the dogs;

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: but they continue always biting him from behind, and making him turn round and round.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: Meantime the man discharges arrows without ceasing, till the animal falls down dead, and thus one man and two spirited dogs are sufficient to kill a large lion.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Cyn-gui and its Lions
sentence: The inhabitants of this province have a good deal of silk, and a great trade is carried on to all quarters along the river.

sectionTitle: Arrival at Sin-din-fu, and Journey back to Gin-gui
sentence: Continuing to journey on its banks for twelve days more, we discover a number of cities and castles.

sectionTitle: Arrival at Sin-din-fu, and Journey back to Gin-gui
sentence: The people are idolaters, subject to the great khan, and use paper money.

sectionTitle: Arrival at Sin-din-fu, and Journey back to Gin-gui
sentence: Some are good at arms, others are merchants and artificers.

sectionTitle: Arrival at Sin-din-fu, and Journey back to Gin-gui
sentence: At the end of the twelve days, the traveller comes to Sin-din-fu,of which mention has been made above.

sectionTitle: Arrival at Sin-din-fu, and Journey back to Gin-gui
sentence: He then rides seventy days through provinces and lands which we formerly went over, and have already described.

sectionTitle: Arrival at Sin-din-fu, and Journey back to Gin-gui
sentence: At the end of that period, he comes to Gin-gui, where we formerly were.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: From Gin-gui or Geo-gui a man travels four days, finding a variety of cities and castles.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: The people are great artificers and merchants, subject to the mighty khan, and use paper money.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: At the end of the four days you come to Ca-cian-fu,a large and noble city, lying to the south, in the province of Cathay.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: The inhabitants are subject to the same monarch, are all idolaters, and burn the bodies of their dead.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: They have a good supply of silk, which they make into different kinds of cloth.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: A large river flows past it, along which great abundance of merchandise is conveyed to Kambalu, with which it is made to communicate by the digging of many canals.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: Now let us pass to another city called Cian-glu.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: The natives are idolaters, subject to the khan, use paper money, and burn the bodies of their dead.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: In that city, salt is made very extensively, and I will tell you how.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: There is a species of earth full of it, and they pile it up in heaps, upon which they throw a great quantity of water, to saturate it with the mineral.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: They next boil it in large cauldrons of iron, till it evaporates, and leaves a white and minute salt, which is exported to all the countries round.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: Five days' journey from Cian-glu is Cian-gli, where are many cities and castles.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: It is a town of Cathay, and the whole people are idolaters, subject to the khan, and use paper money.

sectionTitle: Cities of Ca-cian-fu, Cian-glu, and Cian-gli
sentence: Through the middle of that territory flows a great river, on which is conveyed much merchandise of various kinds.

sectionTitle: Condi-fu--Rebellion against the Great Khan
sentence: In departing from Cian-gli, we come in six days to Condi-fu,a great city, which the khan conquered by force of arms, but still it is the noblest in the province.

sectionTitle: Condi-fu--Rebellion against the Great Khan
sentence: There is a wonderful abundance of silk, as well as orchards with many delicate fruits, and the situation is delightful ;

sectionTitle: Condi-fu--Rebellion against the Great Khan
sentence: it has also under it fifteen other cities of great importance and commerce, whence it derives high honour and dignity.

sectionTitle: Condi-fu--Rebellion against the Great Khan
sentence: In the year 1273, the khan gave to Litan, one of his barons, 70,000 horse to defend and secure that city;

sectionTitle: Condi-fu--Rebellion against the Great Khan
