sentence: but when the said baron had remained some time in the country, he arranged with certain men to betray it, and rebel against his lord.

sectionTitle: Condi-fu--Rebellion against the Great Khan
sentence: When the khan knew this, he sent two of his commanders, Aguil and Mongatai, with many troops, against the traitor.

sectionTitle: Condi-fu--Rebellion against the Great Khan
sentence: On their approach, the rebel went forth to meet them with his forces, consisting of a hundred thousand cavalry and many infantry, both of the country and of those he had brought with him ;

sectionTitle: Condi-fu--Rebellion against the Great Khan
sentence: and there was a very great battle between him and those two chiefs.

sectionTitle: Condi-fu--Rebellion against the Great Khan
sentence: Litan was killed, with many others;

sectionTitle: Condi-fu--Rebellion against the Great Khan
sentence: and the khan caused all those who had been guilty to be put to death, and spared the lives of the rest.

sectionTitle: Condi-fu--Rebellion against the Great Khan
sentence: Now let us tell of another country named Sin-gui.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: When a man has gone south from Condi-fu, he finds cities and castles, many animals of the chase and birds, with a vast abundance of all productions, and then comes to Sin-gui,which is noble, great, and beautiful, with much merchandise and many arts;

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: the whole people are idolaters, subject to the khan, and use paper money.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: They have a river which is of great utility, because the people of the country have divided the stream which comes from the south into two parts;

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: one goes eastward towards Manji, the other westward towards Cathay ;

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: and the land has thus a wonderful number of ships, though not of large size, with which they convey goods to other provinces, and bring thence an almost incredible quantity of merchandise.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: When a man departs from Sin-gui and goes eight days to the south, he finds many rich cities and castles.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: The people are idolaters,subject to the khan ;

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: they burn the bodies of their dead, and use paper money.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: At the end of eight days he arrives at a town named Lin-gui,great and noble, with men-at-arms, and also arts and merchandise.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: Here are wild animals and every kind of provision in abundance.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: When he departs from Lin-gui, he goes three days to the south, finding cities and castles under the powerful khan ;

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: the people idolatrous, and burning the bodies of their dead.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: There is much excellent hunting of birds and beasts.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: At the end of these three days, he discovers a very good city named Pin-gui.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: The people have all things necessary for subsistence, raise much silk, and pay a large revenue to the sovereign.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: A great quantity of merchandise is laden here for the province of Manji.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: When a man has departed from Pin-gui, and travelled two days with his face to the south, through beautiful and rich countries, he finds the city of Cin-gui,very large, and full of merchandise and arts.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: The people are wholly idolatrous, burn the bodies of their dead, their money is paper, and they are under the khan.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: They have much grain and grass.

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: When a man leaves Cin-gui, he finds cities, villages, and castles, with handsome dogs and good pasturage ;

sectionTitle: Cities of Sin-gui, Lin-gui, Pin-gui, and Cin-gui
sentence: the people being such as are above described.

sectionTitle: Of the great River Kara-moran
sentence: At the end of two days a man finds the great river called Kara-moran, coming from the lands of Prester John.

sectionTitle: Of the great River Kara-moran
sentence: It is full, broad, and so deep that a large ship can pass through its channel;

sectionTitle: Of the great River Kara-moran
sentence: and there are on it full 15,000 vessels, all belonging to the khan, meant for conveying his goods when he goes to the islands of the sea, which is distant about a day's journey.

sectionTitle: Of the great River Kara-moran
sentence: And each of these ships requires fifteen mariners, and carries fifteen horses with their riders, provisions, and every thing else necessary for them.

sectionTitle: Of the great River Kara-moran
sentence: When a man passes that river, he enters the province of Manji, and I will tell you how it was conquered by the khan.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: In the extensive province of Manji there was a lord and king named Facfur, who, excepting the great khan, was the mightiest sovereign in the world, the most powerful in money and people ;

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: but the men are not good at arms, nor have horses trained to war, nor experience in battle and military operations, otherwise they would never have lost so strong a country.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: All the lands are surrounded by waters so deep that they cannot be passed unless by bridges, and the chief cities are encompassed by broad ditches filled with water.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: The khan, however, in the year of our Lord 1273,sent one of his barons, Bayam Cinqsan, which means Bayam with the Hundred Eyes: for the King of Manji had found out by astrology, that he could lose his kingdom only by a man having a hundred eyes.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: This Bayam marched with a very great force, many ships, horse and foot, and came to the first city of Manji, called Koi-gan-zu, which we will presently describe.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: He called upon it to surrender ;

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: but the people refused.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: He then went to another city, which also refused, and so he passed five, leaving them behind, because he knew that the khan was sending a large additional force.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: He took, however, the sixth by storm, and then successively reduced other twelve ;

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: after which he marched direct to the capital of the kingdom, called Kin-sai, where the king and queen resided.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: When the monarch saw this great army, he was struck with such terror that he fled from the continent with many of his people, having 1000 ships, and sought refuge among the islands.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: The queen, however, remained and defended herself as well as she could against Bayam.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: But having at length asked what was the name of that commander, and being told it was Bayam with the Hundred Eyes, she remembered the prophecy mentioned above, and immediately surrendered the city to him.

sectionTitle: Of the Province of Manji, and how it was made subject to the Great Khan
sentence: Presently all the cities of Manji yielded, and the whole world does not contain such a kingdom, and I will now describe its magnificence.

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: This King Facfur maintained 15,000 poor children, because in that province many are exposed as soon as they are born by parents who cannot support them;

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: so, when a rich man had no issue, he went to the king and got as many as he pleased.

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: And when the boys and girls came of age, the king married them together, and gave them the means of living ;

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: and thus were educated 20,000 males or females annually.

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: He did another thing : when he went through any place and saw two fine houses, and by the side of them a small one, he inquired why the first were greater than the other ;

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: and being told that it be longed to a poor man, who could not afford to build one larger, presently he gave him money enough to enable him to do so.

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: He made himself be served by more than 1000 domestic servants of both sexes.

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: He maintained his kingdom in such justice, that no evil was done, and all commodities could be left unguarded except by the royal equity.

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: Now I have given you an account of the king ;

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: I will tell you of the queen.

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: She was led to the great khan, who made her be honoured and served asa powerful sovereign ;

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: but the king, her husband, never came out of the islands of the ocean, and died there, and thus the whole kingdom remained with the khan.

sectionTitle: Of the Piety and Justice of the King towards his Subjects
sentence: Now let us tell of the province of Manji, and the manners and customs of the people ; beginning with the city of Koi-gan-zu.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: Koi-gan-zu is a great, rich, and noble city, at the entrance of the province of Manji, lying to the south.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: The whole people are subject to the khan;

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: they are idolaters, and burn the bodies of their dead.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: It lies on the river Kara-moran, and hence is full of ships ;

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: for many merchants bring their commodities thither to be distributed throughout other cities.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: It is the capital of the province.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: Here is made a very great quantity of salt, which is supplied thence to forty different towns;

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: the khan has a large revenue from this and other trades here carried on.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: And now let me tell you of another city called Pau-chym.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: When a man departs from Koi-gan-zu, he goes a whole day along a causeway finely built of stone, and on each side is a large water, so that it is impossible to enter the province unless by this causeway.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: He then finds a city called Pau-chym ;all the people are idolaters, burn the bodies of their dead, and are under the great khan.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: They are artificers and merchants, have abundance of silk, and make much cloth of it mixed with gold, and thus earn a sufficient livelihood.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: Through all that country the paper money of the khan is circulated.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: When a man sets out from Pau-chym, he travels a day and discovers a very large city named Chaym.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: There is great abundance of the necessaries of life ;

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: fish beyond measure, beasts and birds for sport in great numbers, so that for a Venetian silver grosso you may purchase three pheasants.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: Tin-gui is a pretty agreeable city, a full day's journey from Chaym.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: The people are idolaters, subject to the khan, and use paper money ;

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: they have merchandise and arts, and numerous ships belonging to them.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: It lies to the south-east, and on the left, nearly three days' journey to the eastward, is the ocean, where salt is made in great quantities.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Koi-gan-zu, Pau-chym, and Chaym
sentence: Here is a city named Cyn-gui, large, rich, and noble, to which all the salt is brought, and the khan draws from it a revenue so wonderful that it could not be believed.

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Yan-gui
sentence: When a man leaves Tin-gui he proceeds a day towards the south-east,through a very fine country, finding towns and castles, and then comes to Yan-gui,a large and beautiful city, which has under it twenty-four, all good and of great trade.

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Yan-gui
sentence: Its affairs are administered by one of the twelve barons of the khan ;

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Yan-gui
sentence: Messer Marco Polo, of whom this book treats, governed it three years.

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Yan-gui
sentence: Here are made many arms and other equipments for knights and men of war ;

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Yan-gui
sentence: for in this place and around it numerous troops are quartered.

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Yan-gui
sentence: I will now tell you of two great provinces lying to the west, and as I shall have much to say, I will begin with Nan-ghin.

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Yan-gui
sentence: Nan-ghin is a province towards the west, belonging to Manji, and is very noble and rich.

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Nan-ghin
sentence: The people are idolaters, use paper money, and are subject to the great khan.

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Nan-ghin
sentence: They live by merchandise and arts, have silk in abundance, and make cloths of it interwoven with gold, in all fashions.

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Nan-ghin
sentence: They have an ample supply of every kind of grain and provisions ;

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Nan-ghin
sentence: for the land is very fruitful.

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Nan-ghin
sentence: There are also lions and animals for hunting.

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Nan-ghin
sentence: There are many rich merchants who carry on much trade, and pay a large revenue to the great sire.

sectionTitle: Of the great City of Nan-ghin
sentence: But I will now go to the noble city of Sa-yan-fu, respecting which I shall have much to say.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: Sa-yan-fu is a large and magnificent city, having under it twelve others also great and noble;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: it is the seat of many valuable arts and of much merchandize.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: The inhabitants are idolaters;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: they use paper money, are subject to the khan, and burn the bodies of their dead.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: This city held out three years after all the rest of the province had yielded to the conqueror, who besieged it with a mighty army ;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: but he could approach it only on the side which lies to the north, because it was elsewhere surrounded by a large and deep lake, by which the besieged obtained abundance of provisions.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: The army was therefore about to abandon the siege in much grief and wrath, and this news was just brought to the khan, when Messeri Nicolo, Maffio, and Marco Polo said, - we shall find a way by which the city shall be made to surrender.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: The monarch, who was most eagerly bent on its capture, readily listened.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: Then said the two brothers and their son Marco,-Great sire, we have with us in our train men who will make such an engine as will discharge large stones, which the citizens will not be able to endure, and will be obliged to yield.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: The khan was much rejoiced, and desired that they should execute their plan as soon as possible.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: Now, they had in their company a German and a Nestorian Christian who were skilful in such works, and made two or three machines sufficient to throw stones of 300 pounds weight.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: When these were conveyed to the army and set up, they appeared to the Tartars the greatest wonder of the world.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: They then began discharging stones into the city, which struck the houses, broke and destroyed every thing, and caused the utmost noise and alarm.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: When the inhabitants saw a calamity such as they had never witnessed before, they knew not what to think or say.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: They met in council, and concluded that they must be all killed, unless they submitted.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: They therefore intimated to the lord of the host that they would surrender on the same terms that others had done.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: This was agreed to, and Sa-yan-fu came under the power of the great khan, through the interposition of Messeri Nicolo, Maffio, and Marco ;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: and it was not a small service, for this town and province are among the best in his possession, and he draws from them a great revenue.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sa-yan-fu, and how it was taken
sentence: Now, we shall leave this subject and treat of a city called Sin-gui.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: When a man leaves Yan-gui and goes fifteen miles  south-east, he perceives a certain city named Sin-gui, which is not very extensive, but has great merchandise and much shipping.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: The people are idolaters, use paper money, and are subject to the khan.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: That city stands upon a river, named Kiang, which is the largest in the world ; being in some places ten miles broad, and upwards of a hundred days' journey in length.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: Through it the inhabitants have a lucrative trade, which yields a large revenue to the khan.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: And on account of the many cities on it, the ships navigating and the goods conveyed by means of it are more numerous and valuable than in all the rivers of Christendom and the adjacent seas beside.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: I tell you I have seen at that city no fewer than 5000 ships sailing at once on its stream.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: For that river flows through sixteen provinces, and has more than two hundred great towns on its banks.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River

sentence: yet they are of heavy burden, and carry each from 4000 to 12,000 cantars.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: They have ropes composed of cane for drawing them through the water ;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: those belonging to the larger vessels are thick, and fifteen paces in length, being cloven at the end, and bound together in such a way as to make a cord 300 paces long.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: Cai-gui is a small city towards the south-east,situated upon the bank of the above-mentioned river ;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: all the people are idolaters, subject to the khan, and use paper money.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: Here are collected large quantities of corn and rice ;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: and there is a passage by water to the city of Kambalu and the court of the khan;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: grain from this place forms a considerable part of the provision required by his court.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: The monarch made this communication by digging long and deep canals from one river to another, and from lake to lake, so that a large ship may pass through.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: And by the side of this water-channel goes a road, so that you may take either the one or the other, as is most convenient.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: In the middle of that river, opposite the city, is an isle of rocks, on which is a monastery of idolaters, where there are 200 monks, who serve a very great number of gods.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui and the River Kiang, and the Multitude of Cities on that River
sentence: Now, let us cross the river, and tell of a city named Cin-ghian-fu.

sentence: Cin-ghian-fu is a city of Manji, and the peaple are such as we have already described, idolaters, and subjects of the great khan.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghian-fu
sentence: They are artificers, merchants, and hunters, raise much grain, and make cloths of silk and gold.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghian-fu
sentence: Here are two churches of Nestorian Christians, formed in the year 1278 ; which happened because at that time the governor under the khan was a Nestorian, named Marsarchis, and he caused these two edifices to be built.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghian-fu
sentence: Now, let us go to the great city of Cin-ghin-gui.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghin-gui, and of a dreadful Slaughter
sentence: When a man leaves Cin-ghian-fu, and travels three or four days south-east, he always discovers cities and castles, with much merchandise ;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghin-gui, and of a dreadful Slaughter
sentence: the people are all idolaters, subject to the khan, and use paper money.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghin-gui, and of a dreadful Slaughter
sentence: Then he comes to the city of Cin-ghin-gui, great and noble, the people idolaters, and subject to the khan;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghin-gui, and of a dreadful Slaughter
sentence: they have abundance of provisions, produce and manufacture a vast quantity of silk.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghin-gui, and of a dreadful Slaughter
sentence: And here I will tell you a wicked thing which the people of this city did, but it cost them dear.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghin-gui, and of a dreadful Slaughter
sentence: When Bayam, called the chief of the Hundred Eyes, conquered all the province, and took the capital itself, he sent a body of troops to reduce this place.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghin-gui, and of a dreadful Slaughter
sentence: It surrendered, and the soldiers entered and found such good wine, that they drank till they were intoxicated, and became quite insensible.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghin-gui, and of a dreadful Slaughter
sentence: When the men of the city saw them in this condition, that very night they slew them all, so that not one escaped.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghin-gui, and of a dreadful Slaughter
sentence: When Bayam the commander heard of this disloyal conduct, he sent an army who took the town, and put all the inhabitants to the sword.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Cin-ghin-gui, and of a dreadful Slaughter
sentence: Now, let us go on, and I will tell you of another named Sin-gui.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: Sin-gui is a very great and noble city.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: The people are idolaters, subject to the great khan, and use paper money.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: Most of them live by merchandise and arts, raise much silk, make cloths of it interwoven with gold very costly and fine.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: The town is forty miles in circuit, and the number of inhabitants is so great, that no person can count them, and if they were men-at-arms, those of the province of Manji would conquer the whole world;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: they are not so, however, but prudent merchants, and, as already observed, skilful in all the arts.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: They have also many persons learned in natural science, good physicians, and able philosophers.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: The city has 1600 stone bridges under which a galley might pass;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: and in the mountains adjacent grow rhubarb and ginger in such abundance, that for a Venetian grosso you may buy forty pounds of the latter, fresh and good.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: Sin-gui has under it sixteen large cities of arts and trade.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: Its name signifies the earth, and another large town near it is called heaven, and these appellations they derive from their great nobleness.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: Now, let us depart from this place, and I will tell you of another city called Un-gui.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: It is a day's journey from Sin-gui, and is large and good, with merchandise and arts ;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: but there is nothing so remarkable about it as to be worth describing ;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: therefore we shall go on to delineate another called Ughim.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: It is great and rich;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: the men are idolaters, subject to the great khan, use paper money, and have abundance of all things.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: There is nothing else worth mentioning ;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Sin-gui, of Un-gui, and of Ughim
sentence: therefore I will go on to tell you of the noble city of Kin-sai, which is the capital of the kingdom of Manji.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble and wonderful City of Kin-sai and of its Population, Trades, Lake, Villas, and splendid Palace
sentence: When a man leaves Ughim, and goes three days, he observes many noble and rich cities and castles, with great merchandise.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble and wonderful City of Kin-sai and of its Population, Trades, Lake, Villas, and splendid Palace
sentence: The people are all idolaters, subject to the khan, use paper money, and have abundant means of subsistence.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble and wonderful City of Kin-sai and of its Population, Trades, Lake, Villas, and splendid Palace
sentence: At the end of these three days, he finds a very noble city named Kin-sai,which means in our language the city of heaven.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble and wonderful City of Kin-sai and of its Population, Trades, Lake, Villas, and splendid Palace
sentence: And now I will tell you all its nobleness;

sectionTitle: Of the most noble and wonderful City of Kin-sai and of its Population, Trades, Lake, Villas, and splendid Palace
sentence: for without doubt it is the largest city in the world.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble and wonderful City of Kin-sai and of its Population, Trades, Lake, Villas, and splendid Palace
sentence: And I will give you the account which was written by the Queen of Manji to Bayam, who conquered that kingdom, to be transmitted to his master, who thereby might be persuaded not to destroy it.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble and wonderful City of Kin-sai and of its Population, Trades, Lake, Villas, and splendid Palace
sentence: And this letter contained the truth, as I Marco saw with my own eyes.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble and wonderful City of Kin-sai and of its Population, Trades, Lake, Villas, and splendid Palace
sentence: It related, that the city of Kin-sai is 100 miles in circumference, and has 12,000 stone bridges;

sectionTitle: Of the most noble and wonderful City of Kin-sai and of its Population, Trades, Lake, Villas, and splendid Palace
sentence: and beneath the greater part of these a large ship might pass, and beneath the others a smaller one.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble and wonderful City of Kin-sai and of its Population, Trades, Lake, Villas, and splendid Palace
sentence: And you need not wonder there are so many bridges;

sentence: The people are subject to the khan, use paper money, are idolaters, and burn the bodies of their dead in the manner already described.

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: They live by merchandise and arts, and have an ample supply of provisions.

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: And when a man goes three days to the south-east, seeing very large cities and castles, and much trade, he comes to the city of Un-gui,under the government of Kin-sai, and otherwise like the former.

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: When he departs from Un-gui and goes two days south-east, he every where perceives towns and castles, so that he seems to be going through a city.

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: Every thing is in abundance ;

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: and here are the largest and longest canes in all the country, for know that some are four palms in circuit and fifteen paces long.

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: At the end of the two days he comes to Chen-gui,which is large and beautiful.

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: The people, who are idolaters, are under the great khan and the jurisdiction of Kin-sai, and have abundance of silk and provisions.

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: In going four days south-east he finds citiesand castles, and all things in the utmost plenty.

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: There are birds and beasts for the chase, with lions very large and fierce.

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: Throughout all the province of Manji there are neither sheep nor lambs, but oxen, goats, and hogs in great variety.

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: At the end of the four days he finds Cian-cian, a town situated on a mountain, which divides the river into two parts, each flowing in a different direction.

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: The people are like the former ;

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: and, at the end of three days more we reach the city of Can-giu, large and beautiful ;

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: and this is the last under the jurisdiction of Kin-sai;

sectionTitle: Tam-pin-gui and other Cities
sentence: for now commences another kingdom, which is one of the nine parts of Manji, and is called Fu-gui.

sectionTitle: The Kingdom of Fu-gui
sentence: When a man goes from the last-mentioned city of Kinsai he enters the kingdom of Fu-gui ;

sectionTitle: The Kingdom of Fu-gui
sentence: and, after travelling seven days, he finds houses and villages, the inhabitants of which are all idolaters,and under the jurisdiction of Fu-gui.

sectionTitle: The Kingdom of Fu-gui
sentence: They have provisions in great abundance, with numerous wild beasts for hunting ; also large and fierce lions.

sectionTitle: The Kingdom of Fu-gui
sentence: They have ample supplies of ginger and galanga, so that for a Venetian grosso you can buy eighty pounds.

sectionTitle: The Kingdom of Fu-gui
sentence: And there is a fruit or flower having the appearance of saffron, and though not really so, yet of equal value, being much employed in manufacture.

sectionTitle: The Kingdom of Fu-gui
sentence: They eat the flesh of the filthiest animals, and even that of aman, provided he has not died a natural death ;

sectionTitle: The Kingdom of Fu-gui
sentence: but if he has been killed, they account his flesh extremely delicate.

sectionTitle: The Kingdom of Fu-gui
sentence: When they go to war they cut their hair very close, and paint their faces an azure colour like the iron of a lance.

sectionTitle: The Kingdom of Fu-gui
sentence: They fight all on foot except their chief ;

sectionTitle: The Kingdom of Fu-gui
sentence: and are the most cruel race in the world, because they go about the whole day killing men, drinking their blood, and eating their flesh.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: In the middle of these seven days you come to a city called Que-lin-fu,which is very large and beautiful, subject to the great khan.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: It has three bridges, the largest and most magnificent in the world;

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: for each is a mile long and ten paces broad, and all supported by columns of marble.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: The people live by merchandise and arts, and have abundance of silk and ginger.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: The ladies here are very beautiful.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: They have another strange thing, hens that have no feathers, but skins like a cat.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: They lay eggs like those of our hens, and are very good eating.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: And in the remainder of the seven days' journey we discover many cities and castles, merchants and merchandise, and men of art.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: There are lions, great and fierce, doing much injury to the passengers, who on this account cannot travel without imminent danger.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: At the end of the journey is found a city called Un-quem, where there is made such a quantity of sugar, that the whole court of the khan is thence supplied, which is worth a vast treasure.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: Beyond it is the large city of Fu-gui, capital of this kingdom.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: Fu-gui,as just stated, is the capital of the kingdom of Con-cha, which is one of the nine parts of Manji.

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: In that city is much merchandise and art ;

sectionTitle: Of the Cities of Que-lin-fu and Un-quem
sentence: the people are idolatrous, and subject to the great khan.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Fu-gui
sentence: He keeps there a strong army, because the towns and castles often revolt, and whenever they do so the troops hasten thither, take and destroy them.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Fu-gui
sentence: Through the middle of that city flows a river a mile broad;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Fu-gui
sentence: here much sugar is made, and an extensive trade is carried on in precious atones and pearls, which are brought by merchants from India and its isles.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Fu-gui
sentence: It is also near the port of Zai-tun on the ocean, whither come many ships from Hindostan with much merchandise ;

sectionTitle: Of the City of Fu-gui
sentence: and they ascend by the great river to Fu-gui.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Fu-gui
sentence: The people have abundance of all things necessary for subsistence ; fine gardens, with good fruit ; and the city is wonderfully well ordered in all respects.

sectionTitle: Of the City of Fu-gui
sentence: But we will now go on to other matters.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: When one departs from Fu-gui, passes the river, and goes five days south-east, he finds cities and castles, where there is abundance of all things, woods, birds, and beasts, with the tree which bears camphor.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: The people are all idolaters, under the great khan and the jurisdiction of Fu-gui.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: At the end of the five days he finds a city called Zai-tun,which is a noble port, where all the ships of India arrive, and for one laden with pepper which comes from Alexandria to be sold throughout Christendom, there go to that city a hundred.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: It is one of the two best ports in the world, and the most frequented by merchants and merchandise.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: Know, too, that the khan draws thence a large revenue, because all the ships from India pay upon their several kinds of goods, stones, and pearls, ten per cent, that is one in ten.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: The ships take for their freight, on small merchandise, thirty per cent ; on pepper, forty-four ; on lignum, aloes, sandalwood, and other bulky articles, forty;

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: so that merchants, between the freight and the duty, pay a full half of all commodities brought into that port.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: Those of this country are all idolaters, and have great abundance of every thing necessary for the human body.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: In that province is a city, named Ti-min-gui,where they make the most beautiful cups in the world ;

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: they are of porcelain, and are manufactured in no other part of the earth besides that city;

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: for a Venetian grosso you may purchase three cups of this most elegant ware.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: The people of Fu-gui have a language of their own.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: Now, I have told you of this kingdom, which is one of the nine, and the great khan draws from it as much duty and revenue as from that of Kin-sai.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: We have not told you of the nine kingdoms of Manji, but only of three, Manji, Kin-sai, and Fu-gui, and of these you have heard fully ;

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: but the others I cannot now describe, because it would be too tedious, and our book has not yet treated of other things which I wish to write about ;

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: for I have to tell you of the Indians, who are well worthy of being known.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: Their country contains many wonderful things found in none of the other parts of the world, which it will be good and profitable to write.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: And, I assure you, Marco remained so long in  India, and saw so much of its produce, customs, and merchandise, that no man could better tell the truth.

sectionTitle: Of the most noble Port of Zai-tun, and of Ti-min-gui
sentence: Therefore I will put them in writing, precisely as Messer Marco truly said them to me.
You must know there are two Armenias, a great and a lesser one, which last has a king who rules with pure justice, and is subject to the Tartars.
This region contains many cities and castles, and abundance of all things, with beasts and birds for hunting and hawking ;
but I must tell you the air is not very healthy.
The gentry used formerly to be valiant and good at arms ;
but now they are mean and vile, and remarkable only for being hard drinkers.

On the seacoast is a city named Laias,which carries on a very great trade ; for thither all the spices, rich cloths, and other precious articles, are brought from India across the Euphrates, which the merchants of Venice, of Pisa, and of Genoa, come to purchase.
By this town we enter the province of Turcomania.
In Turcomania are three distinct races of men :-The Turcomans adore Mohammed, and are simple people, speaking a very rude language.
They live amid mountains and valleys where there is good pasturage for cattle, by which they subsist ;
and I assure you that they rear excellent horses and mules of great value.
The two others are Armenians and Greeks, who dwell mingled in cities, and subsist by merchandise and manufactures ;
they work carpets and crimson silk, the richest and most beautiful in the whole world.
They have many towns, of which the principal are Como, Casserie, and Sevasto.
They are subject to the Eastern Tartars.
Now, let us leave them, and speak of Armenia the Greater.
Armenia the Greater is a large country, and, at the entrance of it is a city called Arzinga, in which is made the best buckram in the world.
There are several baths of warm spring water, the best and most beautiful any where to be found.
There are many castles, and cities, among which the noblest is Arzinga, the seat of an archbishop, and the metropolis of the whole district;
there are also Argiron and Darzizi.
I assure you the province is very large, and during the summer all the Tartars of the Levant reside here with their flocks and herds, on account of its rich pastures ;
but in winter they cannot remain because of the severe cold and snow, amid which the animals could not live.
Now, in this Armenia is the ark of Noah on a great mountain.
The circuit of its base cannot be traversed in less than two days ;
and the ascent is rendered impracticable by the snow on its summit, which never dissolves, but is increased by each successive fall.
On the lower declivities, the melted snows cause an abundant vegetation, and afford rich pastures for the cattle which in summer resort thither from all the surrounding  countries.
To the south-east it borders on a kingdom called Mosul, inhabited by Jacobite and Nestorian Christians, of whom we will mention more hereafter.
On the north  it extends to the Georgians, and on that frontier is a fountain whence rises oil in such abundance that a hundred ships might be at once loaded with it.
It is not good for eating, but very fit for fuel, for anointing the camels in maladies of the skin, and for other purposes ;
for which reason people come from a great distance for it, and nothing else is burned in all this country.
Now let us quit Armenia, and tell of Georgia.
In Georgia  is a king always called David Melik, which means David the King ;
he is subject to the Tartars ;
and anciently all the monarchs of this province were born with the mark of an eagle on their left shoulder.
They are a handsome people, good archers, and valiant in battle.
They are Christians of the Greek church, and wear their hair close shaven in the manner of clergy.
This is the province which Alexander could not pass through on account of the narrowness of the path
because on one side is the sea, and on the other very high mountains, over which it is impossible to ride ;
and, as this strait continues above four leagues, a few men might hold out against the whole world.
This was the reason why he could not pass;
but he built a very strong tower, that no one might come upon him from the other side, and it is called the Iron Gate.
This is the place mentioned in the book of Alexander, where he enclosed the Tartars within their mountains ;
though the Tartars did not exist at that time, but a certain people called Comani, and other races besides.
There are many cities and castles, with silk in abundance, with which, added to gold, they make cloths the most beautiful that ever man saw.
Here are the finest eagles in the world ; also victuals of every kind in abundance.
The province is full of great mountains, and of narrow passes, so that I can tell you the Tartars could never obtain the entire sovereignty of it.
There is a monastery called St Leonard, containing a great wonder, which I will now relate.

A large lake of water issues from a neighbouring mountain, in which, during the whole year, there is not found a fish great or small, except from the day before Lent down to the evening of Easter Sunday ;
and during the whole of that time fishes are taken in great abundance, but none at any other.
And know that this sea of which I have spoken is seven hundred miles in circuit, and receives the Euphrates, one of the delights of paradise, and many other great rivers.
It is all surrounded by mountain and land;
and lately the merchants of Genoa, who have built ships, navigate it, bringing silk, which is called gelle.
Into this sea the great rivers Herdil,Geihon, Kur, and Aras enter.
In that province there is a grand city named Teflis, with suburbs and fortified posts around it.
The inhabitants are Armenian and Georgian Christians, with some few Mohammedans and Jews.
There are manufactures of silk and other articles.
Now, having told you of the boundaries of Armenia to the north, I will describe those to the south and east.
Mosul is a great kingdom on the eastern border of Armenia, and inhabited by various denominations of men, whom I will now describe.
There is a race called Arabic, who adore Mohammed ;
also another who hold the christian law, but not as the church of Rome commands ;
they err in many things.

They are denominated Nestorian and Jacobite, and have a patriarch named Jatolior, who makes archbishops, bishops, abbots, and other clergy, and sends them to all parts of Bagdad, India, and Cathay, as the pope does from Rome.
All the Christians who are in those parts are of this sect ;
and all the cloths of silk and gold, which are called mosulin, are made there.
I tell you, too, that the great merchants who are called mosulin, and bring the largest quantity of all costly spices, are of this kingdom.
Among its mountains are people called Kurds, who are Nestorian and Jacobite Christians, but some are Saracens, and reverence Mohammed.
They are an overbearing and wicked people, ever ready to rob the merchants.
Now let us leave Mosul, and speak of the great city of Baldach.
At this place dwelt the caliph, chief prelate of all the Saracens in the world, as the pope is at Rome.
Through the middle of it flows a very large river, by which you can proceed to the sea of India, whence merchants go and come with their goods.
From Baldach to the ocean by the stream is a voyage of eighteen days.
The merchants going to India sail down that river to a place named Chisi, and then enter the Indian sea.
Between Baldach and Chisi is a great city named Bascra ;
and the woods around that city yield the finest dates in the world.
In Baldach are many rich cloths of silk and gold, on which birds and beasts are represented ;
and it is the greatest and noblest city in all these regions.
And know, assuredly, that the caliph was found to possess the most abundant treasure in gold, silver, and precious stones that ever was in the possession of man ;
and I will tell you how it happened.

In the year of our Lord, 1255,the great sire of the Tartars, who is named Alau,brother to the great sire that now reigns, assembled a very large army, and marched upon Baldach and took it by force, which was a glorious exploit ;
for it contained more than 100,000 horsemen besides foot soldiers ;
and when it was taken, he found the caliph in possession of a tower full of gold, silver, and other treasure, such as never was seen at once in one place.
When he discovered it he sent for the monarch and said : "Caliph, why have you amassed such a treasure, and what do you mean to do with it?
Did you not know that I was your enemy, and coming to attack you with this mighty host?
Knowing this, why did you not take your treasure, and give it to knights and soldiers to defend you and your city?"
The caliph replied nothing, because he knew not what to say.
Then, said Alau: "Caliph, since I see you love so much your treasure, I will give it you to eat."
He then commanded that he should be shut up in the tower with the treasure, and that nothing should be given to him to eat or drink.
Then he said to him: "Caliph, eat your treasure as heartily as you please, for you will never eat any thing else."
He was then immured in the tower, where he died at the end of four days.
And after him there never was any other caliph.
Toris is a great city, in a province called Yrac, containing many towns and castles ;
but as this is the chief, I will tell you about it.
The men live by merchandise, and by fabricating fine cloths of silk and gold.
The place is so well situated that merchants proceed hither from India, Baldach, Mosul, Cremosor, and many other places.
The Latin traffickers come to meet those from strange countries, from whom they purchase precious pearls and other valuable articles.
The men are of indifferent character and very mixed origin, Armenians, Nestorians, Jacobites, Georgians, and Persians, and some who adore Mohammed.
The inhabitants of the city are called Taurisians.
Around it are very fine gardens, full of fruits and vegetables.
The Saracens here are most wicked and disloyal.
They maintain that whatever is robbed or plundered from men of a different creed is justly acquired ;
while they regard as martyrs those of their own sect who die by the hands of Christians.
If, therefore, they were not checked by their present rulers, they would break out into many outrages.
These principles are common to them all.
At the point of death, the priest comes and demands whether they believe that Mohammed was the prophet of God.
If they profess this belief, they are assured of salvation ;

and through this easy absolution, which leaves scope for the perpetration of every crime, they have succeeded in converting many of the Tartars, who feel thus at liberty to indulge their worst propensities.
Near Toris is a monastery named after St Barsamo, and famous for sanctity.
It contains an abbot and many monks, who dress like the Carmelites.
Unwilling to lead an idle life, they are constantly weaving woollen girdles, which they place on the altar of their saint during divine service ;

and while going round the province to ask alms (as do their brethren of the Holy Ghost), they present these to their friends and persons of distinction, who value them as beneficial in the cure of rheumatism.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: Now I am to tell you of a great miracle which happened between Baldach and Mosul in the year 1225.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: There was a caliph in the former who held the Christians in great hatred, as it is natural for all the Saracens in the world to do.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: He thought day and night how he might compel all those in his country to become converts, or else kill them.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: Many others concurred in that wicked purpose, and they agreed upon this plan : They found in the gospel a text saying that if a Christian had as much faith as a grain of mustard-seed and made his prayer to God, he would be able to join two mountains together.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: On finding this text, they felt great joy, thinking they had thus either a means of converting them, or a pretext for killing them outright.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: He therefore sent for all the Jacobite and Nestorian believers in his country, who were very numerous;

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: and when they came before him, he showed them this gospel, made them read it, and asked if it were true.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: They replied that it was so.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: Then, continued the caliph, since so many Christians are here, there surely must be among you this small measure of faith ;

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: therefore, said he, pointing to a large hill in view, you must remove that mountain, or I will put you all to death, because otherwise you must be wholly destitute of faith, and on that account deserve to die.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: If, however, you will turn to our good law of Mohammed, you shall be forgiven;

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: and, in the mean time, I allow you ten days to do what is required.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: He then dismissed them.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: On hearing what the caliph had said, they were in great fear, and knew not what to resolve.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: Then they all assembled, small and great, men and women, the bishop, archbishop, and priests of whom there were a considerable number, and they remained eight days and eight nights in prayer, that God, in his mercy, and for the diffusion of his faith, would come to their aid, and enable them to escape this cruel death with which they were threatened.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: But what have I now to tell you?

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: While they were thus deeply engaged in prayer, an angel, by the message of God, appeared to a bishop who was a man of very holy life.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: He said, "Oh, bishop!

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: do you now go to a certain shoemaker with one eye, and tell him that at his prayer the mountain will be moved"?.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: Now this shoemaker was a very honest and chaste man ;

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: he fasted and went regularly to mass, and gave every day bread to the poor.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: I will tell you a thing that he did, to prove his good faith and life.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: It happened one day that a very beautiful woman came to his shop to purchase a pair of shoes, and in order to make them fit, he was obliged to look at her foot and ankle, and they were so finely shaped that he felt his eye take an undue pleasure in viewing them.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: As soon as she was gone, he began bitterly to reproach himself, and remembered the text, "if thine eye offend thee, pluck it out, and cast it from thee"?.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: He then took a sharp weapon, and stuck it into his eye, so that it burst in his head, and he never saw with it again.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: Thus you see he was a most holy and good man.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: When, therefore, the bishop had this vision, he told it to all his people, and they agreed that this shoemaker should be called before them, and when he came, they requested him to pray to God that he would make the mountain move.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: But when the shoemaker heard what the bishop and the others said, he answered that he was not so good a man as that God or our lady should for his sake do so great a miracle.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: But the Christians pressed him so earnestly, that he at last agreed, and made the prayer.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: When the final day was come, they all rose early in the morning, great and small, male and female;

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: and entering the church, they sung the holy mass, and then proceeded out to the plain in front of the mountain.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: They were fully a hundred thousand, and they all placed themselves in front of the cross.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: The caliph then came with a vast number of Saracens, eager to slay the unbelievers, for they thought it impossible the hill could be moved, and they themselves were in great fear and doubt ;

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: nevertheless they had good hope in their Creator.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: Then the shoemaker fell on his knees before the cross, lifted his hands to heaven, and prayed fervently that the mountain might be moved, and the Christians there assembled escape a dreadful death.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: When he had made his prayer, it was not long before the vast eminence began to stir, and move from its place.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: The Saracens, on seeing this, wondered greatly, and many of them were converted ;

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: nay, the caliph himself became a believer in the gospel, but secretly, and when he died, a cross was found round his neck;

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: for which reason he was not buried in the same place with the other sovereigns, but in a tomb by himself.

SentenceNo: On a certain Miracle of the Movement of a Mountain in that Region
sentence: Now let us leave Baldach and go to Persia.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: Persia is a very extensive province, anciently very rich and flourishing, but now in a great degree wasted and destroyed by the Tartars.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: It contains a city called Sava, whence the three magi came to adore Jesus Christ when born at Bethlehem.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: In that city are buried the three, in separate tombs, above which is a square house carefully preserved.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: Their hearts are still entire, with their hair and beards.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: One was named Balthazar, the other Gaspar, the third Melchior.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: Messer Marco inquired often in that city about these three magi, but no one could tell him any thing, except that they were ancient kings, who were there buried.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: They informed him, however, that three days' journey farther was a tower called the Castle of the Fire-worshippers, because the men there venerate fire, and for the following reason.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: They say that anciently three kings of that country went to adore acertain prophet, newly born, and carried three offerings, gold, incense, and myrrh, to know if he were a king, a god, or a sage;

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: for they said that, if he took gold, he was a king; if incense, he wasa god; if myrrh, he was a sage.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: They went in one after another, and though they were of different ages and fashions, he appeared to each of them exactly like himself.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: When they came out and compared what they had seen, they wondered much, and then went in altogether, and the child then appeared to them what he really was, a boy of thirteen days old.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: They presented to him the three offerings, and he took them all, whence they concluded that he was at once god, king, and sage.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: He presented to them a closed box, desiring them not to open it till their return home.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: After having travelled a number of days, however, they were curious to see what was in the box, and opened it, when they found only a stone, which was meant to express that they should remain firm in the faith which they had received.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: They did not understand this meaning, and despising the gift, threw it into a well, when immediately a great fire came down from heaven, and began to burn brightly.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: When they saw this wonder, they were quite astonished, and repented that they had thrown away the stone.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: They however took a portion of the fire, carried it to their country, and placed it in their church, where they kept it continually burning.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: They revere it as a god, and use it for burning all their sacrifices ;

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: and when at any time it goes out, they repair to that well, where the fire is never extinguished,and from it bring a fresh supply.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: This is what all the people of that country tell, and Messer Marco was assured of it by those of the castle, and therefore it is truth.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: One of these kings was of Saba, the other of Ava, the other of the castle.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Persia, and the Journey of the Magi
sentence: Now let me tell you of Persia, its cities, and the actions and customs of the people.
Know, then, that in Persia there are eight kingdoms, because it is a very great country, and I will tell you their names.

The first is called Casum ;the second, to the south, Cardistan ; the third Lor ; the fourth Cielstan ;the fifth Istanit ;he sixth Cerazi ;the seventh Soucara ;the eighth Tonocain,which is on the remotest frontier.
In this last are many fine horses of high value, which are taken in large numbers to be sold in India;
and the greater part of them are worth two hundred livres tournois each.
They have also the finest asses in the world, one of which is worth full thirty mares of silver.
The men of that country lead these horses to two cities on the banks of the sea of India, called Chisi and Curmosa, and find there merchants, who buy them and carry them into their distant country.
In these kingdoms there are many cruel men, who are constantly killing one another, and but for the fear of the Eastern Tartars, who now rule in this land, they would ruin the merchants.
As it is, unless the latter are well provided with arms and bows, they often kill or hurt them severely.
These men all hold the law of Mohammed.
In the city are industrious merchants ;
they make robes of silk and gold of various fashions, and raise also plenty of cotton.
The country abounds in wheat, barley, millet, as well asin vines and other fruits.
Some may imagine that the Saracens do not drink wine, as being forbidden by their law ;
but they quiet their consciences by thinking that if boiled over the fire, which renders it milder and sweet, it may be drunk without breaking the commandment.
Changing its taste, they change its name, and no longer call it wine, though it really is so.
Let us now leave them, and tell you of Yasdi.
Yasdi is a beautiful and noble city, with rich manufactures.
The people make silk cloths called by its name, which the merchants carry into various countries.
They all adore Mohammed.
When a man departs from that city, he rides seven days over a plain, where in three places only there are habitations and inns for the traveller.
There are many forests filled with partridges and other birds, which afford excellent sport ; also beautiful wild asses.
At the end of these seven days a country called Creman presents itself.
Creman is a kingdom anciently belonging to Persia, and which used to be governed by a hereditary prince ;
but since the Tartar conquered it, he appoints what deputy he pleases.
In that region the stones called turquoises are in great abundance ;
they are found in the mountains, and excavated from the rocks.
The inhabitants make all things necessary for troops, such as reins, saddles, bows, arrows, quivers, and all kinds of arms, according to the custom of the country.
The ladies work very neatly cloths of gold and silk, representing with the needle, beasts, birds, and many other objects.
In the mountains are reared the finest falcons in the world, for though smaller than the peregrine species, they fly so swiftly that no bird can escape them.
When a man leaves the city of Creman, he travels seven days through towns and fortified places, finding much amusement, because there are great numbers of wild beasts and birds.
At the end of these seven days, he comes to the declivity of a mountain, and continues two days always descending.
There are abundance of fruits, but no habitation, only shepherds pasturing their flocks.
The cold on this road during winter is so great that a man cannot safely travel unless with a very ample provision of clothes.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: At the bottom of this descent is a very extensive plain, at the commencement of which is a city named Camandu,once wonderfully great and noble, but now much declined, because the Tartar invaders have repeatedly plundered it.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: The heat here is extreme, and the province is called Reobarle.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: Its fruits are dates, pistachio nuts, apples of paradise, and others which do not grow in our country.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: Here are a species of birds called francolin, which are different from those of other lands, their colour being a mixture of white and black, while the beak and feet are red.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: The oxen are very large, white as snow, and the hair very smooth, in consequence of the heat.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: Between the shoulders is a hump, two palms high, and their appearance is the most beautiful of any in the world.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: When the owner wishes to load them, they bend down as the camels do, and after receiving their burden, rise and bear it well, being extremely strong.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: There are sheep as large as asses, and with tails so thick and so broad as to weigh full thirty pounds.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: They are also fat, and make excellent food.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: The people have castles and cities surrounded by walls of earth, in order to defend themselves against the Caraunas, a mixed race between the Indians and the Tartars.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: When these people wish to overrun the country and rob it, they, by their enchantment and diabolical agency, cause the day to become dark, so that you can see to little or no distance, and this darkness they make to last seven days.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: They know the places so well, that they can ride during the thickest of it ;

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: and they are sometimes ten thousand in number, so that nothing found on the plain, man, beast, or any thing, can escape.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: They kill the old persons, and carry off the young to sell them for slaves.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: Their king is called Nogodar, and he went to the court of Ciagatai, who was the brother of the great khan, with 10,000 men, and remained with him, because his uncle was very powerful.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: During this stay, Nogodar committed a very great wickedness, and I will tell you what it was.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: He departed from his uncle Ciagatai, who was in Great Armenia, and took with him 10,000 of his people, who were very cruel, and marched by Badasian and through a province called Pasciai, and another called Chesciemur, losing many of his people and beasts, because the roads were narrow and very bad;

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: and when they had passed all these provinces, they entered into India, on the borders of one called Dilivar.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: They came to the city of the same name, and took it from a king called Asidiu Sultan, who was very great and rich.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: There Nogodar, with his people, continues to rule, and makes war with all the other Tartars who dwell in the surrounding country.

SentenceNo: On Camandu, Reobarle, and the Karauna Robbers
sentence: Having told you of this plain, and of the people who produced darkness in order to rob, I must also mention that Messer Marco himself was nearly taken by them amid this gloom, but though a number of his companions were captured, and either killed or sold as slaves, he himself escaped to a castle named Canosalmi.
That plain extends five days' journey southward, and you then come to a descent which continues twenty miles by a very bad and difficult road, full of wicked robbers.

You then approach the very beautiful plain of Formosa, watered by fine rivers, with plantations of the date-palm, and having the air filled with francolins, parrots, and other birds unknown to our climate.
You ride two days through it, and then arrive at the ocean, on which there is a city and fort named Cormos.
The ships of India bring thither all kinds of spiceries, precious stones, and pearls, cloths of silk and gold, elephants' teeth, and many other articles.
It is the capital of a kingdom, having many cities and castles under it, and the sovereign is called Ruemedan Achomac.
The climate, however, is intensely hot, and extremely unhealthy, and when any foreign merchant dies, the king inherits all his property.
Wine is here made of dates and other spices, and is extremely good ;
but when drunk by men unaccustomed to it, has a strong purgative quality, though, after some use, it agrees well, and promotes corpulence.
The people live chiefly on dates and salted fish, particularly the tunny ;
considering these victuals to be the most wholesome, and that if they used wheaten bread and fiesh they would fall sick.

The ships are very bad, and many are lost from not being secured by nails like ours, but sewed together by a thread made of the bark of the Indian nuttrees, which being softened in water, becomes like horsehair, and is durable enough.
They use it for want of iron, but it is by no means strong or secure.
They have a mast, sail, and rudder, all single, and a coverlet of leather, which is spread over the goods, and on that they place the horses, many of which are transported into India.
These ships, too, are not tarred, but covered with the oil of fish.
The people are black, and adore Mohammed.
They do not remain in the city during summer, for then they would all die, but retire to the country, where they have verdant gardens, finely watered by streams.

Even there they would not escape, because there often blows from the sandy tracts that surround the city a wind so excessively hot that it would kill them all, if they did not plunge into the water and thus escape it.
They sow wheat, barley, and other kinds of grain in the month of November, and reap them in March, when they become ripe and perfect ;
but none except the date will endure till May, being dried up by the extreme heat.
I have also to tell you, when men or women die, great grief is shown, and the ladies, during full four years after the death of their husbands, make lamentations at least once a-day.
On these occasions, they assemble their relations and neighbours, who join them in loud moanings and cries.
In proof of the extreme violence of the heat, Marco Polo mentions the following circumstance which occurred during his residence.
The ruler of Cormos neglected to pay his tribute to the King of Creman, who took the resolution of enforcing it at the season when the principal inhabitants go in to the country.
He therefore despatched 1600 horse and 5000 foot through the district of Reobarle, to take them by surprise.
Being misled, however, by the guides, they did not reach the place till night, when they halted to rest in a grove near the town.
On renewing their march next morning, they were attacked by the hot wind, and all suffocated ;
not one surviving to carry back the fatal intelligence.

When the people of Cormos learned this event, and went to bury the dead bodies lest they should infect the air, they found them so softened by the intense heat, that the limbs, when handled, separated from the trunks ;
and it was necessary to dig graves close to where the corpses lay.
We will now leave this city, and not go on to India, for I will describe it farther on in my book, in the proper time and place.

We will return, therefore, by another road to Creman, because the countries now to be delineated can be reached only by way of that city, and I must tell you that Ruemedan Achomac, of whom we have just spoken, is subject to its king.
The route in returning thither from Cormos is through a very fine plain.
