There are many springs whence the water issues in a hot state, forming baths very salutary in cutaneous and other diseases.
Here is abundance of fruits and dates, also of partridges and other birds ;
but the wheaten bread, owing to the quality of the water, is so bitter that no one unaccustomed to its use can eat it.
I now wish to tell you of a country lying to the north.
When a man has left Creman, he travels seven days in that direction, through a very dreary region.

During three days he finds no river, and the little water met with is salt, green like grass, and so bitter that it is impossible to drink it, and if a man tastes even a drop, it produces violent purging.
Travellers, therefore, carry water with them ;
but the beasts being obliged to drink such as they find, suffer severely.
The whole tract is an arid desert, destitute of animals, which could not find food.
On the fourth day, you reach a river of fresh water, but with its channel mostly under ground.
In some spots, however, the force of the current makes abrupt openings, when the stream appears for a short space, and drink is abundantly supplied.
Then follows another tract that lasts four days, and is also a dry desert, with bitter water, and no animals except wild asses.
At the end of the four days, we leave the kingdom of Creman and proceed towards Cobinam.
Cobinam is a great city inhabited by Mohammedans.
There is abundance of iron, brass, and andanico, of the second of which they construct large and beautiful mirrors;
they make here also the tutty, which is extremely good for the eyes, and likewise sponge, in the following manner.
They take a vein of earth fitted for this purpose, and throw it into a burning furnace, above which is a grating of iron;
then the smoke and moisture ascending adhere to the iron and form tutty, while the earth which remains in the furnace becomes sponge.
When a man departs from Cobinam, he goes through a desert of eight days, and the country is very arid;
there is neither fruit nor trees, and the water is bitter and bad, so that he must carry both it and food for himself, but the beasts drink that on the road, though very unwillingly.
He then comes to a province called Tonocain, with cities and many castles, bordering upon Persia towards the north;
and there is a very great plain on which grows what the Christians call the dry tree, which I will describe to you.
It is very large, and its leaves are green on one side and white on the other.
It yields a nut like the chestnut ;
but there is nothing within it.
It is a strong wood, and yellow like box ;
and there is no other tree in those parts for a hundred miles round, except on one side, at ten miles' distance.
It is said by the people of the country to be the place where Alexander fought with Darius.
There are many towns and castles, and the inhabitants have abundance of all good things, the climate being neither too cold nor too hot.
Now I must tell you of a country called Mulecte, where the Old Man of the Mountain used to dwell.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: You shall learn all about the Old Man of the Mountain, as I Marco heard related by many persons.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: He was called in their language Alaodin, and had caused to be formed, in a valley between two mountains, the largest and most beautiful garden that ever was seen.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: There grew all the finest fruits in the world, and it was adorned by the most beautiful houses and palaces, the interior being richly gilded, and furnished with finely coloured pictures of birds and beasts, and the most striking objects.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: It contained several conduits through which flowed respectively water, wine, honey, and milk.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: Here were ladies and damsels unequalled in beauty and in the skill with which they sung and played on instruments of every description.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: Now the Old Man made his people believe that this garden was paradise, and he formed it thus because Mohammed had given the Saracens to believe that those who went into that place would meet great numbers of beautiful women, and find rivers of water, wine, milk, and honey;

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: hence the visiters were led to think that this really was paradise.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: Into this garden he admitted no man except those whom he wished to make assassins.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: The entry to the spot was commanded by a castle so strong that he did not fear any power in the world.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: He kept in his court all the youths of the country between twelve and twenty years of age, and when he thought proper, selected a number who had been well instructed in the description of paradise.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: He gave them a beverage which threw them into a deep sleep, then carried them into the garden, and made them be awakened.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: When any one of them opened his eyes, saw this delightful spot, and heard the delicious music and songs, he really believed himself in the state of blessedness.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: When again, however, he fell asleep, he was brought out into the castle, where he awoke in great wonder, and felt deep regret at having left that delightful abode.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: He then went humbly to the Old Man, worshipping him as a prophet.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: Being asked whence he came, he told that he had been in the paradise described by Mohammed, relating all he had seen, and saying that he desired much to die and return thither.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: The chief then named to him a great lord whom he wished him to kill.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: The youth cheerfully obeyed, and if in the act he was taken and put to death, he suffered with exultation, believing that he was to go into the happy place.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: If, after performing the deed, he escaped, the Old Man received him with the greatest honour, and when he wished to destroy another chief, employed him afresh, saying that he was sent into paradise.

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: Thus scarcely any person could escape being slain, when the Old Man of the Mountain desired it;
Person: the Old Man of the Mountain

SentenceNo: On the Castle of the Old Man of the Mountain, and how he trained and employed his Assassins
sentence: and many barons became vassals to him through the dread of thus losing their lives.

SentenceNo: How Alau took and killed the Old Man of the Mountain
sentence: Having now told you of the Old Man of the Mountain and his assassins, you shall hear how he was killed.
Person: the Old Man of the Mountain

SentenceNo: How Alau took and killed the Old Man of the Mountain
sentence: I had forgot to mention, that he had other old men placed under him, one of whom he sent into the country of Damascus, and the other into Kurdistan.

SentenceNo: How Alau took and killed the Old Man of the Mountain
sentence: But now let us come to his destruction.

SentenceNo: How Alau took and killed the Old Man of the Mountain
sentence: It was in 1262 that Alau, the Lord of the East, having heard of his wicked deeds, determined to destroy him.

SentenceNo: How Alau took and killed the Old Man of the Mountain
sentence: He sent his generals with a great body of men, who besieged the castle full three years, and then could only reduce it by famine.

SentenceNo: How Alau took and killed the Old Man of the Mountain
sentence: Alaodin being taken, was killed, with all his people, and since that time there has been no assassin ;

SentenceNo: How Alau took and killed the Old Man of the Mountain
sentence: and thus ended his dominion and his wickedness.

SentenceNo: Of a certain City named Sapurgan
sentence: When a man departs from that castle, he rides through beautiful hills covered with rich herbage, with fruits and all things in great abundance.

SentenceNo: Of a certain City named Sapurgan
sentence: The country extends to a journey of six days, and contains cities the inhabitants of which adore Mohammed.

SentenceNo: Of a certain City named Sapurgan
sentence: Yet sometimes you find a desert of fifty or sixty miles, without water, which men must carry with them.

SentenceNo: Of a certain City named Sapurgan
sentence: When the traveller has rode six days through the country now described, he finds a city called Sapurgan.

SentenceNo: Of a certain City named Sapurgan
sentence: It has great abundance of all things, among which are the finest melons in the world in great plenty, and they are preserved in this manner: The people cut them all round like cucumbers, and dry them in the sun, when they become sweeter than honey, and are sold through all the country.

SentenceNo: Of a certain City named Sapurgan
sentence: Here is fine hunting of beasts and birds.

SentenceNo: Of a certain City named Sapurgan
sentence: Now I will go on to another city named Balk.
Balk is a great and noble town, and was anciently still more so;
but the Tartars have spoiled and wasted it, so that many beautiful houses and palaces of marble are now destroyed.
It was here, as I was told by the people, that Alexander took to wife the daughter of Darius.
The people revere Mohammed ;
and at this point ends the dominion of the Eastern Tartars, this city being the boundary of Persia, between north-east and east.
Now let us tell of another country named Dogana.

On leaving Balk, you ride two days between north-east and east, and find no habitation, because the people have all fled to the fortresses in the mountains for fear of wicked men, who lay waste the land.
There is no want of water or game, and lions are also seen.
No food is to be procured, but travellers must carry it both for themselves and their horses.
When a man has rode these two days, he finds a castle called Taikan,where there is a great corn-market, and the country round is fine.
The mountains towards the south are very high, and formed entirely of salt, which is the best in the world, and people come for it from a distance of thirty days' journey round.
It is so hard, that it can be broken only by great iron hammers ;
and there is enough to supply the whole human race till the end of time.
Departing from that city, you go three days north-east, through a fine country, well planted with grain and fruits.
The people, who are followers of Mohammed, are wicked and murderous.
They spend much time in the tavern, for they have abundance of good wine, well prepared.
They wear nothing on their heads but a cord ten palms long wrapt round it.
They are good hunters, and thus supply themselves with venison ; but have no clothing except the skins of animals.
When a man travels three days, he finds a city named Scassem, which is on the plain, while the others are on the mountains, and through it flows a considerable river.
There are here many porcupines, and when the hunters set their dogs upon them, the hogs collect together and push their spines against their assailants, and often hurt them severely.
This Scassem is a large province, and the shepherds dwell in caverns on the mountains, which are easily formed, being wholly of earth, and make large handsome habitations.
When a man leaves this city, he travels three days without finding a house, or any thing to eat or drink, being obliged to carry provisions with him, and he then enters the district of Badascian.
Badascian is a large province, whose people adore Mohammed, and have a language of their own.
It is governed by kings descended from Alexander and the daughter of Darius lord of Persia, and all these kings are called in Saracen Zulcarnem, which means in their language Alexander.
In this country occur the precious stones called balasiu, which are very beautiful and valuable.
They are found in the rocks of a mountain called Lighinan, and are cut out of very deep caverns, as is done by those who work silver mines.
Know, too, that the king makes them be worked out for himself, and no other man may cut out balasiu on that mountain, on pain of death.
His majesty sends them as presents to other princes and great lords, either as homage, or in token of friendship, and he likewise sells them for gold and silver.
The prohibition is enforced that they may continue valuable ;
for if all persons were allowed to dig for them, they would be quite depreciated.
You must likewise know, that in other mountains of the same country are found the stones of which ultramarine is made, and it is the finest and best in the world.
There are also lofty hills containing veins yielding silver in abundance.
The country is extremely cold, but it breeds very good horses, which run with great speed over these wild tracts without being shod with iron.
There are found also the falcons called sacri, which fly well and swiftly ; also those called lanier ; and there is abundant hunting of beasts and birds.
Wheat and good barley are plentiful ;
they have no oil of olives, but make it from sesamum and nuts.
This kingdom has many a narrow pass and strong post to secure it against the entrance of enemies, and the cities and castles are strongly built on high mountains.
The people are good archers and hunters, and mostly clad in the skins of beasts, on account of the scarcity of cloth.
The great ladies, however, wear from sixty to a hundred yards of bombasine wrapped round their body, in order that they may appear very fat, because the men delight in such a shape.

On the summits of the mountains the air is so pure and salubrious that the inhabitants of the towns and lower valleys, when attacked by fever or other inflammatory complaints, immediately remove thither, and in three or four days recover their health.
Marco Polo affirms, that he himself experienced its excellent effects ;
for after being confined nearly a year by sickness, he was advised to try change of air by ascending the hills, and he then immediately regained his strength.
You are to know that ten days south from Badascian is a province called Pascia.
The people have a peculiar language ;
they are worshippers of idols, and much skilled in enchantments and diabolical arts.
The men wear ear-rings and buckles of gold and silver, with pearls and precious stones.
They are a very artful and malicious people.
The province is extremely hot, and the people live upon flesh and rice.
Now let us leave it, and tell of another, which is distant from this seven days towards the south-east.
Kesimur is inhabited by idolaters, who have a language of their own.

They have a wonderful knowledge of the enchantments of devils, making their images speak, and by sorcery changing the seasons, causing great darkness, and doing other wonders which could not be believed unless they were seen.
The idols of this province are the heads over all the others, and went down hence to the neighbouring countries.
The people are meagre and of a brown complexion ;
but the females are very beautiful.
They live on flesh and rice, and have a number of cities and castles.
They have woods and deserts, and passes so strong that they have little dread of an invader: their king rules with great justice.
In this country are hermits, who observe great abstinence in eating and drinking, and carefully abstain from all offences against their faith ;
and this is done through veneration of their gods.
They have abbeys and monasteries, are held in much reverence by the people of the country, and live to a great age.
The coral brought from our land is sold more readily there than in any other nation.
From this place you may go to the sea of India, and if we went farther we should enter into that country ;
but being to return that way, we will then describe it in due order, and now go back to Badascian.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: When a man departs from Badascian, he goes twelve days between north-east and east, along a river which belongs to a brother of the lord of that land.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: There are many castles, and a good number of inhabitants, who are valiant and adore Mohammed.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: He then comes to a province named Vokhan, not very large, being only three days' journey in every direction.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: The people are of the same description, and subject to the ruler of Badascian.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: Wild beasts and birds of every kind for hunting are most abundant.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: Having left this place, and travelled three days, always over mountains, he ascends to a district which is said to be the highest in the world.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: Here he finds a plain between two vast hills, through which flows a very fine river, issuing from a large lake ;

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: and it is the best pasturage in the world, for a lean animal becomes fat here in ten days.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: All kinds of wild animals abound ;

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: in particular, a species of sheep with horns of three, four, and even six palms long.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: These are formed by the shepherds into large spoons, out of which they eat ; and are even employed in enclosing the places where they keep their cattle.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: The hornsare heaped up in large quantities along the road, for the purpose of guiding travellers during winter, when it is covered with snow.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: While a man passes for twelve days along this high plain, which is called Pamier,he sees neither habitation nor verdure, but must carry all his provisions along with him.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: No birds can live in this cold region;

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: and I can even state that the fire does not burn so clear nor with the same colour as in other places, nor does it cook victuals so well.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: Leaving this place, he has to go on forty days between north and north-east, and passes many rivers and deserts ; and in all this journey finds neither verdure nor habitation, but must carry all his provisions along with him.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: This country is called Belor.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: The people live in very lofty mountains.

SentenceNo: Of the Countries of Vokhan, Pamier, and Belor
sentence: They are idolaters, extremely savage, violent, and cruel, subsist by hunting, and dress themselves in the skins of beasts.
Cascar was anciently a kingdom, but is now under the dominion of the great khan.
The people adore Mohammed, and have cities and castles;
they are situated between the north and east.
They subsist by merchandise and manufactures, having also fine gardens, vineyards, and orchards, with a good supply of silk.
The merchants, in carrying on their trade, go round the whole world ;
but they are sordid and covetous, eating and drinking very poorly.
Some Nestorian Christians reside here, observing their own customs and laws.
The people have a language of their own ;
and the province extends five days' journey.
Now let us leave it and speak of Samarcan.
Samarcan is a very great and noble city, lying to the south, inhabited by Christians and Saracens.
The people are governed by a nephew of the great khan, who, however, is not his friend, but is in open hostility against him.
I have to tell you a great wonder which happened in this city.
You must know that not very long since, Ciagatai, brother to the great khan, became a Christian, and was lord of that and of many other countries.
The believers of Samarcan rejoiced greatly at his conversion, and erected a large church in honour of it, bearing the name of St John the Baptist.
They took a large and fine stone belonging to the Saracens, and made it the base of a column, which rose in the middle of the edifice, and supported the whole roof.
Now it came to pass that Ciagatai died, whereupon the Mohammedans, having been much enraged at this stone being taken for the use of the church, consulted with each other how to recover it by force.
This they could now easily do, being ten to one of their adversaries.
Several of their elders went and told the Christians that they wished to receive back the slab, which had been formerly theirs.
The latter answered, that they would willingly restore it, but for the injury it would do to their building, and offered to pay a fair price for it.
The others replied, that they wished neither gold nor treasure, but must have their stone.
The government now belonged to the nephew of the great khan, who commanded that within two days it should be restored.
When the Christians received that order, they were much grieved, and knew not what to do.
They went, however, and with many tears implored John the Baptist to relieve them in this tribulation.

On the morning of the day when the stone was to be returned, the pillar, by the power of our Lord, rose up at least three palms, and supported itself as well as when the stone was beneath it, and has continued to do so till this day.
This was and still is accounted one of the greatest miracles that ever happened in the world.
Now let me tell you of a province which is called Yarcan.
Yarcan is a province five days' journey in length.
The people obey the law of Mohammed, but there are some Nestorian Christians;
they are subject to the nephew of the khan mentioned above.
All necessaries are in great abundance.
Cotton is also grown, and the inhabitants are skilful artisans.
They suffer severely by swellings in the legs and in the throat, occasioned by the bad quality of the water.
Finding nothing else worth mentioning, I shall go on to Cotan.

SentenceNo: Of the great Province of Cotan
sentence: Cotan is a province between north-east and east, and is eight days' journey in length.

SentenceNo: Of the great Province of Cotan
sentence: The people adore Mohammed ;

SentenceNo: Of the great Province of Cotan
sentence: they have a number of cities and castles.

SentenceNo: Of the great Province of Cotan
sentence: The capital is a noble town, called by the name of the kingdom.

SentenceNo: Of the great Province of Cotan
sentence: They have all things in abundance, a large supply of silk, with vineyards and good orchards.

SentenceNo: Of the great Province of Cotan
sentence: They carry on merchandise and manufactures, but are not men at arms.
Pein is a province five days' journey in length, between north-east and east.
The people adore Mohammed, are subject to the great khan, and have a number of towns and castles.
The noblest city and capital is called by the name of the kingdom.
Here is a river in which are found the stones named jasper and calcedony.
The people are very well supplied with necessaries, and grow a good deal of silk.
They live by merchandise and arts, and have a custom which I will now tell you.
When a woman has a husband who has gone a journey, and is to be absent above twenty days, as soon as he has departed she takes another partner, being fully allowed  by usage to do so;
while the husband, in the place where he goes, takes another wife.
Know that all the provinces now described from Cascar to the present, and still farther on, belong to Great Turkey.
Now let us tell of a province named Ciarcian.
Ciarcian is a province of Great Turkey, lying between north-east and east, with a capital city of the same name.
The people adore Mohammed, and have a good number of towns and castles.
There is a river bringing jasper and calcedony, which, being of excellent quality, they take to sell in Cathay, and thus make great profit.
This province is sandy, as well as the whole road from Cotan hither ; and much of the water is bad and bitter, but in various places it is good.
When an enemy passes through the country, they flee with their wives, children, and cattle, two or three days' journey through the sand to places abounding in fine water and pasturage ;
and no one can tell where they have gone, because the wind blowing the sand obliterates all traces of their march, and they thus escape the invader.
But when a friendly army passes through, they send away only the beasts, because the troops would take and eat them, without any payment.
After departing from Ciarcian, you go five days through the waste, finding the water bad and bitter, but occasionally sweet and good.
At the end of these five days you come to a city which lies at the commencement of the great desert, wherein provisions are laid in for its passage, and therefore I must tell you about it.

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: Lop is a large city at the entrance of the great desert bearing its name, and lying between the east and northeast.

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: It belongs to the khan, and the people adore Mohammed.

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: You must know that those persons who wish to pass this tract rest in the city a week to refresh themselves and their cattle ;

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: then, having taken a month's provisions and provender, they enter upon the desert, which I assure you is so extensive that if a man were to travel through its whole length, it would employ a year ;

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: and even at its smallest breadth, a month is requisite.

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: It consists altogether of mountains and valleys of sand, and nothing is got to eat;

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: but after travelling a day and a night, you find sweet water sufficient for from fifty to a hundred men, with their animals.

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: A larger body could not be supplied.

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: Thus, water is seen daily, or altogether in about twenty-eight places, and except in three or four it is good.

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: Beasts or birds there are none, because they could not find food;

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: but there is a great wonder which I must now tell you.

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: When a party rides by night through this desert, and any one lags behind, or straggles from his companions through sleep or any other cause, when he seeks to return to them, he hears spirits speak to him in such a manner that they seem to be his comrades, and they frequently call him by name, and thus lead him out of his way so that he never regains it, and many persons are thus lost and perish.

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: I must tell you, too, that even by day you hear these voices of spirits, and even tambours, and many other instruments sounding.

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: They find it necessary, also, before going to rest at night, to fix an advanced signal, pointing out the course to be afterwards held ;

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: likewise to attach a bell to each of the animals, that they may be more easily kept from straggling.

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: In this manner, amid much danger and fear, this desert is passed.

SentenceNo: Of the City and Desert of Lop
sentence: Now we must tell you of the countries that lie on the other side.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: When you have rode thirty days through this desert, you find a city named Sacchion,which belongs to the khan.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: The province is called Tangut,and the people are idolaters, mixed with some Nestorian Christians and Saracens.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: The first have languages of their own ;

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: they subsist not by merchandise, but by the grain which they produce from the earth.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: They have many abbeys and monasteries, all full of idols of various shapes, to which they offer frequent sacrifices and homage.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: Every man who has children rears a sheep, and at a particular festival at the end of the year, leads them along with that animal into the presence of the god, to whom they all perform reverence.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: They cook the sheep and offer it very humbly before the idol, leaving it while they make their prayers for the safety of their children.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: They then take the meat and carry it to the house, or wherever they please, send for their relations, and eat it with great joy and respect.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: They afterwards collect the bones, and preserve them with much diligence.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: You must know likewise, that when any one of them dies, his body is burned, and after he is carried to the place for this last ceremony, they erect in the middle of the path a house of cane, covered with cloths of silk and gold.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: When the dead man is laid before this ornamented house, they place before him wine and victuals, believing that he will be similarly honoured in the other world.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: At the place of burning, too, they cut in paper, men, horses, camels, and coins of the size of bezarits, convinced that the deceased will possess all these things in the future state.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: On this occasion, all the instruments in the land are sounded before the corpse.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: I must tell you, too, that after death the relations send for the astrologer, who is informed of the day, month, and year of his nativity, and then divines, by his diabolical art, the day on which the burning ought to take place.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: If it should be a week, a month, or six months, they keep it all that time, and never burn it till the appointed day.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: During this interval, they deposit it in a large box covered with cloth, and so preserved with crocus and other spices that no stench arises.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: Throughout this period, they place daily before the box meat and drink, and leave it there for some time, till they think he has eaten it.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: These sorcerers, too, often tell the relations that the dead body must not be carried out by the main door, but by a private one, or even through a breach made in the wall.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: All the idolaters in the world proceed in this manner.

SentenceNo: Of the Province of Tangut and City of Sacchion
sentence: Now I must go to another city which lies to the south, near the extremity of this desert.
Kamul is a province, formerly a kingdom, containing cities and castles, with a capital of the same name.
It stands between two deserts, the great one already described, and a smaller one, extending three days' journey.
The people are all idolaters, and have a peculiar language ;
they live by the fruits of the earth, having enough to eat, and also to sell to the passenger.
They are men of great gaiety, thinking of nothing but to sound musical instruments, to sing, dance, and delight their hearts.

When a stranger comes to lodge in a house, the master is highly pleased, and leaves him with his wife, desiring her to treat him in every respect as a husband, while he himself goes and spends two or three days elsewhere.
All the men of the province proceed in this manner, and do not account it any disgrace.
The women are handsome, gay, and fond of diversion.

Now, when Mangou Khan reigned as sire of the Tartars, it was reported to him how the people of Kamul gave over their wives to strangers, when he sent orders that, under a severe penalty, travellers should not be henceforth entertained in this manner.
When they received this injunction, they were greatly grieved, held a council, and did what I will now tell you.

They made up a large present, and sent it to Mangou, praying that he would allow them to treat their wives according to the custom handed down to them by their ancestors, who, for this kindness to strangers, had gained the favour of their idols, and their corn and other crops had greatly multiplied.
When he heard this message, he said, Since you are so bent on your own shame, let it be so?.
He allowed them, therefore, to do as they pleased, and hence they have always maintained this custom.
Ginghintalas is a province which is near the desert, between north and south, sixteen days' journey in extent, and subject to the great khan.
It contains cities, castles, and three descriptions of men, idolaters, adorers  of Mohammed, and Nestorian Christians.
On the borders of it, towards the north, is a mountain containing a very abundant vein of copper and antimony.
There is also one from which is made the salamander;
but do not suppose this is the animal so called, for no creature can live in fire, because it is compounded of the four elements.
It is only through ignorance that the salamander is called an animal ;
and a Turk, named Zurficar, who was very learned, and governor of this province for three years under the great khan, being much employed in working the mines, gave me an account of it.
When this ore is taken from the mountain, and is broken, it strings together, and forms a thread like wool.
Being then dried, pounded in a large mortar, and washed, there remains that thread of which I have spoken.
Being then woven like wool, it forms cloth, which is dingy in colour at first, but when placed and left some time in the fire, it becomes white as snow, without dirt or stain.
This is the truth of the salamander, and every thing else said about itis mere fable.
I can tell you, too, that at Rome there is a cloth which the great khan sent to the pope as a costly present, and the sudarium of our Lord was placed within it.
Now let us tell you of other provinces to the south-east and east.
When you have departed from the province now described, you go ten days in the same direction.
In all that way there are few habitations, nor does any thing occur worth mentioning.
You then find a district called Succiur,with a capital of the same name.
The people are Christians, and idolaters, and under the great khan.
All the three provinces last described belong to the general one named Tangut.
Through all its mountains, rhubarb is found in great abundance, and the merchants purchase and carry it over the whole world.

They cannot, however, take this road through the mountains with any animals but those accustomed to the country, because a poisonous plant grows there, which, when eaten, causes the hoofs to drop off ;
but the native cattle, having learned its dangerous quality, carefully avoid it.
They live by the fruits of the earth, but attend little to merchandise.
Now I must tell you of another city.
Canpicion is a great and noble town, chief and capital of the whole province of Tangut.
The people are idolaters, and there are some who adore Mohammed, and also Christians who have three large and beautiful churches.

The first have monasteries and abbeys according to their custom, with a very great number of idols, some of which, I assure you, are ten paces high, severally formed of wood, of earth, and of stone, all beautifully covered with gold and ivory.
Their priests live more respectably than others, and guard themselves against luxury, though they do not hold it for a very great sin.
They observe the lunar months like ours, and in one of them do not kill any beast or bird.
For five days they eat no food that has had life, and live more strictly than usual.
They take sometimes thirty wives, or as many as they have wealth to maintain, and give them a dowry in beasts, slaves, and money ;
but the first wife ranks always as the principal.
If any of them do not please him, she may be divorced.
They marry their cousins and even the wives of their father, and do not regard as sins many things which we account great ones ;
for they live like beasts : therefore let us leave them and go to the north.
But I must tell you that Messeri Nicolo, Maffio, and Marco, remained in that city a year, on particular business which I need not enter into.
We shall now go sixty days northwards.
After riding twelve days, you come to a city named Ezina,which is at the northern extremity of the desert of sand, and still in Tangut.
The people, who are idolaters, breed camels and other beasts, and have falcons of different species and of good quality.
They live by the fruits of the earth and cattle, and are also employed in merchandise.
In this city, a man lays in provisions for forty days, during which time, travelling from Ezina northwards, there is neither habitation nor inns.
But the people, except during summer, remain in the valleys;
and in the mountains they find a number of wild beasts, especially asses: there are also pine-forests.
At the end of these forty days they reach a northern province, and you shall hear what it is.

Karakorum is a city three miles in circuit,which was the first that the Tartars took when they issued from their country, and I am to tell you of their actions and manners, how they gained command, and spread themselves over the world.
You must know that they dwelt in the north, about Ciorcia, in which region are great plains, and no abode in cities or castles, but good pasturage, large rivers, and abundance of water.
They had no lords, yet paid tribute to the great sire, named in their language Unchan, whom we call Prester John, and who is spoken of over all the world.
They paid to him one beast out of every ten;
but they multiplied so greatly, that he became afraid of them, and resolved to separate them into different countries;
for which purpose he sent his barons among them.
The Tartars on hearing this were much grieved, and, holding a council, determined to flee through desert countries to the north, where he could not reach nor injure them.
They then ceased to obey or pay tribute to him,and remained thus for a long time.

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: Now it happened that, about 1187, the Tartars appointed a king, who was named in their language Gengis Khan.

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: He was a man of great worth, sense, and prowess;

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: and let me tell you, when he was elected, all the Tartars in the world that were scattered through those strange countries came and owned him as their lord.

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: He maintained his power with great vigour, and the multitudes who ranged under his standard were almost innumerable.

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: When he saw so numerous an army, he went conquering other countries, and made himself master of eight provinces ;

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: yet he neither injured nor robbed the people of any thing, but placing them under leaders in whom he could confide, led them on to other triumphs.

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: Thus he overthrew, as you have heard, a multitude of nations ;

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: and seeing his good command and mildness, they cheerfully followed him, upon which he formed the design of subduing a great part of the world.

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: In the year 1200, he sent a message to Prester John, asking his daughter to wife.

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: Hereupon that monarch was very indignant, and said,-What impudence is this in Gengis Khan?

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: Knows he not that he is my man and my vassal?

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: Return, and tell him that I would burn my daughter sooner than give her to him, and that he deserves to be put to death as a traitor and disloyal to his lord.

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: He then desired the messengers to depart forth with, and never return.

SentenceNo: On Gengis, the first Khan of the Tartare
sentence: They presently went away, and coming to their master, told him in order all that the other had said.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: When Gengis Khan heard this boastful speech, his heart swelled, so that it almost burst within him ;

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: for you must know he was a man of very great pride.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: He then said to his minister, and to all about him, that he would not continue to hold the sovereignty, unless Prester John were made to pay more dearly for this villany than ever man did, and he must soon be made to see whether he was his vassal.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: Then he summoned round him the greatest army that ever was seen or heard of, and sent notice to Unchan that he must defend himself, as he was coming against him.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: When that prince knew certainly the approach of Gengis with so great a force, he made light of it, saying, they were not men-at-arms ;

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: yet resolved that should he approach, he would do all in his power to take and put him to death.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: He then ordered all his people to be prepared and summoned from many and strange parts,and a greater host and of more formidable aspect was never seen.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: And why make a long story?

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: The khan, with all his people, came to a great and beautiful plain, named Tenduc, in Prester John's country, where he pitched his camp, and rejoiced greatly to hear that his enemy was coming, because it was an excellent situation for giving battle.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: He sent for his astrologers, who were Christian and Saracen, and required to know which would conquer in that battle, he or his antagonist.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: The latter could tell nothing of the truth ;

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: but the former showed it openly;

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: for they brought before him a cane, cut in the middle, and placed the two parts on different sides, and wrote the name of Gengis on one, and of Unchan on the other, telling him, that when they had made their enchantment, he whose cane should come above that of the other would conquer in battle.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: He desired that this should be shown to him as soon as possible.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: Then they took up the Psaltery, read certain portions, and performed their enchantment, when presently the cane on which was the name of Gengis, without any one touching it, joined the other, and mounted above it, and this was witnessed by all present.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: When he saw this, he was greatly rejoiced, and seeing that the Christians were men of truth, held them always in great honour.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: Two days after, the armies engaged, and it was the greatest battle that ever was fought.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: The slaughter was terrible on both sides;

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: but at length Gengis conquered, his enemy was slain in the engagement, and he himself became master of all his land.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: From that day he went on conquering many castles and provinces, and reigned six years ;

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: but, at the end of that time, he besieged a fort, named Cangui, where he was wounded in the knee by an arrow, and died.

SentenceNo: His Battle with Prester John, and Victory over him
sentence: This was a great misfortune, for he was a brave and wise man.

SentenceNo: On the Khans who reigned after the Death of Gengis
sentence: After the death of Gengis, the next khan was Cui, the third Bacui, the fourth Alton, the fifth Mangou, the sixth Kublai,who is greater and more powerful than all the rest;

SentenceNo: On the Khans who reigned after the Death of Gengis
sentence: for the other five together had not so much power as this Kublai ;

SentenceNo: On the Khans who reigned after the Death of Gengis
sentence: nay, let me tell you, that all the emperors in the world, and all the Christian and Saracen kings, do not equal him, as is shown fully in our book.

SentenceNo: On the Khans who reigned after the Death of Gengis
sentence: Now you must know that the great lords of the lineage of Gengis Khan are buried in a lofty mountain called Altai, and whenever the chief lords of the Tartars die, if it should be a hundred days' journey distant, they must be conveyed thither to be interred.

SentenceNo: On the Khans who reigned after the Death of Gengis
sentence: I will tell you another striking wonder ;

SentenceNo: On the Khans who reigned after the Death of Gengis
sentence: that when the bodies of the khans are carried to these mountains, the conductors put to the sword all the men whom they meet on the road, saying, Go and serve the great lord in the other world ;

SentenceNo: On the Khans who reigned after the Death of Gengis
sentence: and they do the same to the horses, killing also for that purpose the best he has, You must know that when Mangou died, more than 20,000 men were slain, who had been met on the road when his body was removed to be buried.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: Now since I have begun speaking of the Tartars, I will tell you many things about them.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They abide during winter in plains and warm situations, where there is abundant herbage for their cattle;

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: and in summer they retire to cool places on mountains and high valleys, where water abounds.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They have wooden houses covered with felt, of a round shape, which they convey with them wherever they go;

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: for they have them so well bound with twigs as to be easily carried.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: Whenever they take down and set up a house, the gate is always placed to the south.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They have waggons so well covered with black felt, that if it should rain the whole day, no water would reach any thing within ;

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: and they are drawn by oxen and camels.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: On the top they place their wives and children ;

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: and I must tell you that the ladies buy, sell, and perform all the work necessary for their husbands, who do nothing but hunt, hawk, and go to war.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They live on flesh, milk, and the produce of hunting, and likewise on rats of Pharaoh, which are found here in great numbers.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They eat also the flesh of camels, dogs, and indeed of every kind of animal, and drink mare's milk.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They shun the seduction of married females, as a most vile and shameful thing;

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: and the wives are very faithful, performing extremely well the business of the household.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: Every man may take as many as he pleases, even to a hundred, if he can maintain them ;

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: yet they hold the first as the principal and most respectable.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They scruple not to marry their cousins, and if the father dies, the eldest son may take all his wives, except his own mother ;

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: he marries also the widow of his deceased brother.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They celebrate their marriages by great festivals.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: The Tartars, who believe in a deity of a sublime and heavenly nature, burn incense in censers to him, and pray that he may preserve them in health of mind and body.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They have also one called Nacygai, whom they call their earthly god, who guards their children, cattle, and corn.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They fashion him of felt and cloth, keep him in their house, and pay him great honour and reverence.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They make for him also a wife and children of cloth, placing the first on his left hand, and the latter in front.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: Before eating, they take the fat meat and anoint his mouth with it; then lay bread before the door of his chamber.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: Having done this, they say that their god and his family have had their share, and sit down to their own meals.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: I told you that they drink mare's milk, but it is in such a manner that it seems white wine, being of an agreeable taste, and called chemius.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: The wealthy wear rich robes of gold and silk, with varied furs of the ermine, sable, and fox.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: Their harness is beautiful and of great value;

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: their arms are bows, swords, and clubs ;

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: but the first is more used than the others, because they are excellent archers.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: On their back they wear armour of buffalo and other very strong hides.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: I will tell you the manner in which they maintain justice.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: If a man has stolen an article of little value, they give him seven lashes, or seventeen, or twentyseven, going on thus always to three hundred and seven, and many die under them.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: If he steals a horse or any thing else for which he deserves to die, he is cut through the middle with a sword;

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: yet if he can pay nine times the value of what he has stolen, he is allowed to live.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: Every lord or other man, who owns oxen or any cattle, makes them be marked with his seal, and then allows them to feed on the plains or among the mountains ;

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: and whoever finds one straying brings it to him whose mark is upon it.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: The sheep and lambs, however, are guarded by a shepherd.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: Their cattle are all remarkably large, fat, and beautiful.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They have another wonderful custom which I had forgot;

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: for when two men have one a son, the other a daughter, dead at the age of four, they marry them together, and represent the union by cards, which they set on fire, and when they see the flame and smoke ascending, they make great shouts and run backward and forward, saying that the dead are going to their children in the other world, and are to be husband and wife there.

SentenceNo: On the Religion, Customs, and Manners of the Tartars
sentence: They do more, for they paint on cards the similitudes of men, horses, cloths, bezants, and harness, then burn them, and say that all these things will be possessed by their children in the other world.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: The Tartars are good men-at-arms in battle, capable of much endurance;

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: and they can go through more warlike toil than other men.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: Often, when necessary, one of them will remain a month without any food, except the milk of a mare and the flesh of animals killed by him in hunting, his horse feeding on the grass, without his needing to bring barley or straw.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: He is very obedient to his master, and when necessary will remain the whole night armed on horseback.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: They are the men in the world most capable of enduring fatigue and trouble, subsisting at the least expense, and best fitted for conquering lands and kingdoms.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: They arrange their armies in the following manner.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: When a Tartar lord goes to war, he has with him 100,000 men.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: He places a chief over every ten, every hundred, every thousand, every ten thousand, so that each officer, even the commander of the hundred thousand, has to deal only with ten persons;

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: for he gives his orders to the chiefs of ten thousand, they to those of one thousand, they to those of a hundred ;

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: and thus every man answers to his captain.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: The hundred thousand is called a tut, and ten thousand a toman.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: When the armies are marching through plains and mountains, they send 200 men two days in advance, also behind and on each side, so that they cannot he attacked by surprise.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: And when they are marching a long way they carry no baggage, but merely two large leathern bags, in which they put their milk, and a little earthen pot for cooking their victuals.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: They take a small tent, under which they remain during rain.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: And I tell you also, that when necessary they ride full ten days without food, and without lighting a fire;

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: but piercing a vein of their horse, they drink his blood.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: They have likewise their milk dried into a species of paste, which, when about to use, they stir till it becomes liquid and can be drunk.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: When they go to battle with their enemies, they conquer in this manner: they apparently betake themselves to a shameful flight, for they have so trained their horses that they turn round and round like dogs.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: And when they are fleeing and hotly pursued, they fight as well as when they face the enemy ;

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: for in their swiftest flight they wheel about and discharge their arrows, which kill both men and horses of the opposite army, who, when they think their adversaries discomfited and vanquished, fall themselves one after the other.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: When the Tartars have thus made a great slaughter, they turn and rush on so violently, that they soon gain a complete triumph.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: All that I have told you here applies to the genuine Tartars ;

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: but they are now much altered ;

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: those who live in Cathay have adopted the manners and customs of the idolaters ;

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: those in the Levant imitate the Saracens.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: I have said nothing here of the mighty acts of the great khan, the sire of all the Tartars, nor of his splendid imperial court ;

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: for these wonderful things are described elsewhere in this book.

SentenceNo: On their Wars, and the Order of their Armies
sentence: But let us now return to our route on the great plain where we were when we began to speak of their actions.

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: When you depart from Karakorum, and from Altai, where the khans are interred, as I have related above, you go northwards through a country which is called the plain of Bangu, and continues during a journey of forty days.

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: The inhabitants, who are called Mecri, and are very savage, live on the flesh of animals, chiefly deer, nay I assure you that they ride upon these animals.

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: Their customs resemble those of the Tartars, and they are subject to the great khan.

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: They have neither corn nor wine, but in summer abundance of beasts and birds for hunting and hawking ;

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: though in winter none remain in the country on account of the intense cold.

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: After travelling these forty days you come to the ocean ;

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: and there is found a mountain, where the peregrine falcons build their nests.

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: You must know this place contains neither men nor women, nor beasts, nor any birds, except one species, which is called barghenlac, on which the hawks feed.

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: They are of the size of partridges, have feet like parrots, and tails like swallows, and they fly very swiftly.

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: When the great khan wishes peregrine falcons, he sends thither for them.

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: In an island of that sea, too, are bred the gerfalcons;

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: and I assure you the place is so far north, that the polestar remains behind, and is seen to the south.

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: Those birds are bred on that isle in such abundance, that the great khan obtains as many as he pleases;

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: while others are conveyed to Argon and other lords of the East.

SentenceNo: On the Plains of Bangu and the extreme Parts of the North
sentence: Now that I have told you of these northern provinces as far asthe ocean, let us return to Canpicion.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: When a man departs from that city, he goes five days eastward through a country where there are many spirits, who are often heard speaking during the night.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: You then find a kingdom called Erginul,belonging to the great khan, and included in the large province of Tangut.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: There are a good many towns, the chief one bearing the same name ;

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: and the people are a mixture of Nestorian Christians, idolaters, and Mohammedans.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: Proceeding thence south-east, you come into the country of Cathay, when you will find in the way a city named Singuy.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: There are a good many other towns, still in Tangut, and subject to the great khan;

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: and the inhabitants are as above described.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: There are a vast number of wild oxen, as large as elephants, and very beautiful, their back being entirely covered with white and black hair, three palms long.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: These animals are also caught and tamed, when they do twice as much work as the common ox.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: This country, too, produces the best musk in the world, and I will describe the animal by which it is supplied.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: It is small, about the size of an antelope, which it resembles in the feet and tail, but has a soft thick hair like the stag, no horns, only four teeth, two above and two below, three inches long and very sharp.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: It is a beautiful creature;

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: and, on its being taken, there is found a bag between the skin and the flesh, containing a bloody imposthume, which, when the skin is cut through, is drawn out, and forms the musk whence issues so strong an odour.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: In this country it is very abundant, and of good quality.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: The people also raise plenty of corn,and engage in merchandise and manufactures.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: The region extends to a journey of full twentyfive days.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: There are pheasants twice as large as ours, with tails from seven to ten palms long.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: Others resemble ours;

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: and there are various birds, with finely coloured wings.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: The people, who are idolaters, are fat, with small noses, black hair, and no beard unless on the chin.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: The ladies have no hair except on the head, and are every way very handsome.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: The men are voluptuous, and are authorized by their law and usage to take as many wives as they can maintain.

SentenceNo: On the great City of Erginul
sentence: If a woman is beautiful, though of humble birth, a great baron readily espouses her, giving to her mother such a sum of money as may be agreed on.
When a man departs from Erginul, and goes eight days castward, he finds a province of Tangut called Egrigaia, where there are cities and castles, and the chief one is named Calacian.
The people are idolaters ;
yet there are three towns held by Nestorian Christians.
They are subject to the great Tartar;
and in this city is made cloth of camels' hair, the most beautiful and valuable in the world.
There is a kind of wool whence they manufacture very fine white camlets in great quantities.
These the merchants convey by many routes to Cathay and other parts throughout the world.
Now let us go to Tenduc, in the territory of Prester John.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: Tenduc is a province towards the east,where there are cities and castles, and the chief one bears the same name.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: The people belong to the great khan, like all those formerly subject to Prester John.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: In this province there is a king named George, descended from that prince, and who indeed enjoys his power.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: He holds the land under the khan, but only a part of that which was possessed by his ancestor.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: I assure you, however, that the khans have often given their daughters and female relations to the reigning kings of this line.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: In this province are found the stones whence azure is made ;

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: they are plentiful and good.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: Camlets, too, are woven of camels' hair.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: The natives live on cattle and the fruits of the earth, and have likewise some merchandise and manufactures.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: The Christians, as already mentioned, are masters of the land ;

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: but there are also idolaters and worshippers of Mohammed.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: There is likewise a people called Argon, meaning in French Guasmul, that is, mixed of two different races.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: They are handsomer than the others, more prudent and commercial.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: Know that in this province was the chief seat of Prester John, when he ruled over the Tartars and all the surrounding countries ;

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: and this George is the sixth in succession from him.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: This, too, is the place which we in our country call Gog and Magog, but they call it Ung and Mungul ;

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: and in each province was a different race of people,-in Ung were the Gog, and in Mungul dwelt the Tartars.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: When a man rides through that province seven days eastward towards Cathay, he finds many cities and castles.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: The inhabitants are Mohammedans, idolaters, and Christians ;

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: they carry on trade, and manufacture fine gilded cloths, called nascisi, with various kinds of silk cloth, and are subject to the great khan.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: There is a city named Sindacui, with many manufactures of harness and trappings necessary for an army.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: In the mountains of that country is a place named Idifu, where there is a very productive silver mine.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: They have no want Of beasts and birds for hunting.

SentenceNo: On the Province of Tenduc, and of Gog and Magog
sentence: Now let us depart from this province and its cities, and travel three days, when we shall find a town named Cianganor, in which is a fine palace of the great khan.
Departing from this city, and travelling three days between north and north-east, you come to another named Chandu,built by Kublai, the great khan now reigning.
Here he has built a most magnificent palace.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: Having described so many inland provinces, I will now enter upon India, with the wonderful objects in that region.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: The ships in which the merchants navigate thither are made of fir, with only one deck, but many of them are divided beneath into sixty compartments, in each of which a person can be conveniently accommodated.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: They have one rudder and four masts ;

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: while some have two additional, which can be put up and taken down at pleasure.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: Many of the largest have besides as many as thirteen divisions in the hold, formed of thick planks mortised into each other.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: The object is to guard against accidents which may cause the vessel to spring a leak, such as striking on a rock or being attacked by a whale.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: This last circumstance is not unusual ;

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: for during the night the motion of the ship through the waves  raises a foam that invites the hungry animal, which,  hoping to find food, rushes violently against the hull,  and often forces in part of the bottom.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: The water,  entering by the leak, runs on to the well, which is always kept clear ;

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: and the crew, on perceiving the occurrence, remove the goods from the inundated division, and  the boards are so tight that it cannot pass to any other.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: They then repair the injury and replace the articles.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: The  plaiJ^ are double, fastened with iron nails, and plastered  without and within, but not secured by pitch, of which  the people are destitute.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: They therefore take lime, beat  it into fine powder, and mix it with an oil from trees, so  that it becomes equal to glue.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: These vessels carry two  hundred mariners, and five or six thousand loads of  pepper ;

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: they are moved by oars, on each of which four  hands are employed.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: Every one of them has two barks,  large enough to carry a thousand loads, and forty seamen  well armed, who often assist in dragging the large ships.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: Ten small boats are also kept for fishing and various other services ;

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: two being attached to each bark.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: When the ships have sailed a year, and stand in need of repair, a fresh plank is fastened above the two others, then nailed and cemented, till they sometimes acquire a depth of six planks.

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: Having thus described the merchant-vessels that go to India, I will tell you of the country itself ;

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: but first I must mention the many isles in this sea lying to the eastward ;

SentenceNo: India and the Ships navigating thither
sentence: and first, of one named Zipangu.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: This is a very large island, fifteen hundred miles from the continent.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: The people are fair, handsome, and of agreeable manners.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: They are idolaters, and live quite separate, entirely independent of all other nations.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: Gold is very abundant, and no man being allowed to export it, while no merchant goes thence to the mainland, the people accumulate a vast amount.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: But I will give you a wonderful account of a very large palace, all covered with that metal, as our churches are with lead.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: The pavement of the chamber, the halls, windows, and every other part, have it laid on two inches thick,so that the riches of this palace are incalculable.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: Here are also red pearls, large, and of equal value with the white, with many other precious stones.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: Kublai, on hearing of this amazing wealth, desired to conquer the island, and sent two of his barons with a very large fleet containing warriors, both horsemen and on foot.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: One was named Abatan, the other Vonsanicin, both wise and valiant.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: They sailed from Zai-tun and Kin-sai, reached the isle, landed, and took possession of the plain and of a number of houses ;

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: but they had been unable to take any city or castle, when a sad misadventure occurred.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: A mutual jealousy arose amongst them, which prevented their acting in any concert.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: One day when the north wind blew very strong, the troops expressed to each other apprehensions, that if they remained, all the vessels would be wrecked.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: The whole then went on board and set sail.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: When they had proceeded about four miles, they found another small isle, on which, the storm being violent, a number sought refuge.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: Others could not reach it, many of whom suffered shipwreck and perished ;

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: but some were preserved and sailed for their native country.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: Those who had landed, 30,000 in number, looked on themselves as dead men, seeing no means of ever escaping ;

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: and their anger and grief were increased, when they beheld the other ships making their way homeward.

SentenceNo: Island of Zipangu, and Tartar Expedition thither
sentence: The sovereign and people of the large isle rejoiced greatly when they saw the host thus scattered and many of them cast upon the islet.
